text: nucleus of the nature that everything obtains its meaning and value.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The _Whole_ consequently grows, and gradually man becomes conscious of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: his personality as over against the environing world and even his own
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: body. This consciousness of [p.36] _inwardness_ is of slow growth,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: because the natural tendency of life is to give a primary place to the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world from which we have emerged--the world of physical existence, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: also because much of that physical world reigns powerfully within our
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature. But when reflection turns into itself, it becomes aware that the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: inwardness constitutes the kernel of a reality higher in its nature than
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: anything either in the physical world or in the physical life which the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: man has to lead.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Two modes of reality now present themselves to the life, neither of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which allows itself to be conceived of as an illusion. On the one hand,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: we find the physical world and our own physical nature. We discover that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: we cannot jump out of these without destroying all we possess; we have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to come to some kind of understanding with the physical world and our
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: own physical existence. Yet, on the other hand, the consciousness of a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: kernel of our being, non-sensuous and spiritual in its nature, has for
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ever broken our satisfaction with the physical world and our own
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: physical existence. There are only two alternatives on which we can act.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Either we are to conceive of our spiritual personality as something
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: secondary and subsidiary to the natural world, or we are to insist on
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its independence, and acknowledge it as the beginning of _a new mode of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: existence._ If the former alternative is chosen, the personality can
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: never pass to a state of self-subsistence, [p.37] but will conceive of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality as something which is mainly physical. The consequence is that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the personality will suffer seriously in its evolution, for such an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: evolution is brought about through the recognition and willing
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: acknowledgment of the breaking forth of _a new kind of reality_ within
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the spiritual nucleus of life. If the latter alternative is chosen, this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nucleus of life is now seen as something quite other than a quality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: entirely dependent upon the physical or than a mere flowering of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: physical; it is seen as a reality higher in its nature than the physical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: or even than the ordinary life of the individual. Such a situation is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: forced on man when once he reflects upon the inward meaning of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: content of his consciousness. It is true that such questions may be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: thrust into the background, and consequently inhibited from presenting
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: us with their full value and significance. And it is this which happens
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: only too often in daily life. The constant need of attention to external
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: things, the absorption of the mind in conventionality and custom as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: these present themselves in the form of a ready-made inheritance--all
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: these occupy so much of the attention as to prevent man from knowing and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: experiencing what _his own life_ is or what it is capable of becoming.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Man has penetrated into the secrets of Nature as well as into the past
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of human society through close and constant attention to external
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: things. [p.38] He has been able to gather fragments together, piece them
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into each other, and through this frame laws concerning them. It is thus
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that the external world and society have come to mean more to a human
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: being than to an animal. The animal is probably almost entirely the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: creature of its instincts and of the percepts which present themselves
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to it from moment to moment, and which largely disappear. But man rises
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: above this situation. The external world and everything that has ever
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: happened on its face are not merely objects external to himself, which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: contain all their qualities in themselves. Somebody has to experience
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: all this, and that somebody that experiences all this is _mental_ in his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature, however much this nature has been conditioned by _physical_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: things in the past or present.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eucken emphasises this fundamental fact in all his books. Wherever a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: being is capable of _experiencing_ impressions and of giving _meanings_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to these, we are bound to conclude that the power which does this is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something quite other than physical in its nature. It may be that such
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a power has never been known except in connection with what is physical;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it may be that various chemical changes give the truer and clearer
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: explanation of its origin, as far as its origin can be known at all;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it may be that there was nothing of the _mental_ visible in the early
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: stages of its development; but all this is very different from stating
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that [p.39] no potentiality for mental evolution was there. And it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this potentiality which is the issue at stake. We have no warrant for
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: stating that it does not exist because it does not lend itself to be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: verified by the senses. Where does _mind_ manifest itself to the senses?
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: It is something which does not exist in space as a horse or a tree. It
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: may be that consciousness has emanated from simple chemical beginnings
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and combinations, but it is not a simple or a chemical thing _now_. We
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: divide worlds into inorganic and organic. The main principle of division
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is necessitated on account of the fact that some characteristics are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: present in the former which are absent in the latter. It is precisely
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the same between Body and Mind, with one difference. Body and Mind are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: indissolubly connected, but one cannot be reduced into the other.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: However much the connection on one side may influence the other side,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the difference between a _meaning_ and a _thing_ remains. And it is this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fundamental difference which makes it absolutely necessary to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: acknowledge _a world_ of consciousness in contradistinction to a world
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of matter and its behaviour, whether such matter is to be found in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: human body with its mechanical and chemical changes and transformations
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: or in the physical universe outside our body.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: It is only when the mind becomes aware of its own existence--an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: existence not to be established as being in Space (or entirely in [p.40]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Time) but as a reality subsisting in itself and in will-relations--that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the efforts and fruitions of the spirit of man become intelligible at
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: all. But such an awareness has become a permanent possession in a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: greater or less degree within the life of man. Whenever he becomes
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conscious of the fact that in his own soul a new phenomenon has made its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: appearance, he begins, after the willing acknowledgment of the reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of such a phenomenon, to exercise its potency over against the external
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world and over against much that is present in his own psychical life. A
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Higher and a Lower present themselves to him. The two alternatives force
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: themselves, and there is no third: either this deeper kernel of his life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: must mean the possibility and, in a measure, the presence of _a new land
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of reality_; or, on the other hand, it means no more than a mere
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: epiphenomenon and blossoming of the merely _natural_ life. If the latter
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: view is adopted, the spiritual nucleus of man's nature obtains but
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: slight attention except on the side of its connection with the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: surrounding organic world, and consequently what this nucleus is in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: itself as an experience recedes into the background, and descriptions
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and explanations in scientific or philosophical form step into the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: foreground. But a contradiction is imbedded in this very account. Some
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: kind of experience of life, apart from, and higher in its nature than,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the connection of the spiritual nucleus with its [p.41] physical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: history, persists in the life. The man of science is generally a good
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and worthy man. He believes in the moral life, and he does not throw the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: values of the centuries overboard. Such belief and valuation are not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: made up of the content of the explanation of life from its physical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: side, but are an unconscious acknowledgment of the presence of _truths
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and values as experiences and as now subsisting in themselves_, however
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: much they are caused by physical things.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: If, on the other hand, an acknowledgment of the reality of this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual life is made, new questions immediately arise. And the most
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fundamental of these questions have always been those farther removed
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: from any sensuous or physical domain. They are questions concerning the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: value and meaning of life. It is a deep conviction of the reality of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deeper kernel of our being that alone constitutes the entrance to a _new
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: kind of world_. But to acknowledge the presence of such a new world does
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: not signify the possession of it simultaneously with the acknowledgment.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The new world is discovered, but it is not yet possessed. There are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: terrible obstacles in the way; there are enemies without and within to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be conquered. It is of little use entering into this struggle without an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: acknowledgment--born of an inward necessity--of the spiritual nucleus of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: our nature. Unless man has accustomed himself to hold fast to this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: "subtle thing termed spirit" [p.42] he will soon be swamped in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: region of the natural life once more; and when this happens the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual nucleus loses the consciousness of its own real subsistence as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something higher in its nature than physical things or than the body and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the ordinary life of the day. If the enterprise is to issue in anything
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that is great and good--into a spiritual world with an ever-growing
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: content here and now--an insistence upon the reality of this deeper life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: coupled with the highest end which presents itself to the life must be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: made. Something is now seen in the distance as the meaning and value of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life--something which our deeper nature longs for, and which has created
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a cleft within the soul between the ordinary things of sense and time
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and that which "never was on sea or land." It is something of this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature which Eucken discovers as the germ of all the spiritual ideas of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion as well as of the essence of religion itself. The Godhead,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eternity, Immortality, are concepts which arise within the soul through
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a consciousness of the inadequacy of all natural things and of even
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mental descriptions and explanations to answer and to satisfy the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: potency and longing of human nature.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Most of the great thinkers of the ages have insisted on the necessity of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the recognition and acknowledgment of this deeper life which is in dire
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: need of a content. If man is not to be swamped by the external and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: become the [p.43] mere sport of the "wind and wave" of the environment,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: he has to enter somehow into the very centre of his being and become
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: convinced that the dictates which proceed from that centre are the most
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fundamental things in life. This has always formed the kernel of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion, however often men, failing to reach that kernel, have lived on
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the husks. But even this very sham notifies some small attempt in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: right direction. In modern times--in the various forms of Idealism and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Pragmatism--such a need of getting at the core of being and of being
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: convinced that the effort is worth while, has been emphasised again and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: again. "_Launch yourselves with as strong and decided an initiative as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possible_. Accumulate all the possible circumstances which shall
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: re-enforce the right motives; put yourself assiduously in conditions
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that encourage the new way; make engagements incompatible with the old;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: take a public pledge, if the case allows; in short, envelop your
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: resolution with every aid you know. This will give your new beginning
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: such a momentum that the temptation to break down will not occur as soon
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: as it otherwise might; and every day during which a breakdown is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: postponed adds to the chances of its not occurring at all."[8]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: "The Stoic and Butler also said, 'Follow God.' In each case you must
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: realise that, whatever you do, you take your life in your [p.44] hands;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: you enter on a grand enterprise, a search for the Holy Grail, which will
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: bring you to strange lands and perilous seas. For you cannot say,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: interpreting, 'Thus far and no further, merely according to the bond and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the duty.' In following God, you follow by what has been, what is ruled
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and accomplished, but you follow after what is not yet. 'It may be that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the gulfs will wash us down'; it may be that the gods of the past will
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: rain upon us brimstone and horrible tempest. But he that is with us is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: more than all that are against us. Whoever keeps his ear ever open to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: duty, always forward, never attained, is not far from the kingdom. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: gods may be against him, the demi-gods may depart; but he, as said
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Plotinus, 'if alone, is with the Alone.'"[9]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: It is impossible for us, as Eucken constantly insists, to stop short of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this. Who can prescribe limits to the capability of consciousness when
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it is focussed, in the form of a conviction, on the deepest problems
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which press themselves upon it? There is only one objection that the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: empiricist can bring forward, and that is that all such ideals can never
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be proved to exist as things exist in space. But, as already hinted, is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: existence in space the only form of existence? Is it not necessary for
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something which is _not_ in space to make us aware of what is in space?
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: "If not as men of science, yet as [p.45] men, as human beings, we have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to put things together, to form some total estimate of the drift of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: development, of the unity of nature."[10]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: If the deepest core of consciousness is acknowledged and the vague
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ideals and ends which present themselves are attended to, _something new
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: happens_ in the life. Life now starts on the great enterprise referred
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to by William Wallace. It finds its highest reality in an experience
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: born within itself and differentiated for ever from the natural and even
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the intellectual life. To such a conclusion man is forced; and if the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: situation is evaded, something within his soul never comes to birth. It
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is seen at once that in order to know the content of this _new world_,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it is necessary for a long series of struggles to take place. And to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this point we now turn.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The deeper consciousness has relegated the natural world to a secondary
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: place, and has further shown man that the main object of life includes
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: not only finding a footing against the dangers of natural things, but to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: plant oneself within a spiritual world of meanings and values. This
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: cannot be done without _an independent and decisive act of the soul_. A
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: meaning of life has now revealed itself beyond that of the "small self."
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: This meaning can be reached only through this decisive act of the soul.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: This meaning is _over-individual_ in its nature; [p.46] it is a truth,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: goodness, or beauty, which presents itself as an idea and ideal formed
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: by the experiences of many individuals, at different epochs and in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: different circumstances. Thus the individual, in order to realise his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: own life, must work with material presented in the community. Such
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: material has been found helpful in the life of the community. It
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consists of collective results made up of large numbers of single
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: factors. These have been tied together in the form of various syntheses.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Such various syntheses comprise a larger meaning than what ordinarily
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: happens from moment to moment in connection with the relation of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual to the external world or, indeed, within the individual's own
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ordinary life. Many of the isolated, fragmentary experiences of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual have to give way when tested in the light of any larger
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: synthesis. If this were not so, no commercial, social, civilised life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: would be possible at all. The more real life is now perceived to be that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the larger meaning and value. The individual, solitary experiences
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: may be legitimate, for they often express wants and needs of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual which have a certain right to obtain satisfaction. But the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: extent and limits of these rights have to be measured by some norm or
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: standard other than themselves, or else each individual will proceed on
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: his own course regardless of the rights of others. It is the presence of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: various syntheses which express the [p.47] collective life of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: whole--of each and every individual--that makes civilisation possible.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Thus, in the very process of civilisation itself, as Eucken points out,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: there is present a factor which is termed Spiritual, and which is not to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be mistaken for a mere flow of cause and effect, or for one mere event
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: following another. Eucken emphasises this all-important element of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: over-individual qualities present in human history. There is here much
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which resembles Hegel's Absolute. But there is a great difference
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: between the two in the sense that Eucken shows the constant need of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual activism on the part of individuals in order to realise and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: keep alive the norms and standards which have carried our world so far;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and there is also the need of contributing something to the values of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: these through the creation of new qualities within the souls of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individuals themselves.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But the problems of civilisation and morality are not the only, or the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: highest, problems which present themselves. But even such problems have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: partially been the means of drawing man outside himself, and of enabling
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: him to see that his self can only be realised in connection with the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: common good and demands of the community. He now feels the necessity of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: living up to that standard. This is an important step in the direction
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the moral and religious life. It reveals the presence of a spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nucleus of our being obtaining a content beyond the needs [p.48] of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: moment; it shows life as realising itself in wide connections; and the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual becomes the possessor of a certain degree of spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: inwardness in the process. Even as far as this level we find the deeper
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life--the spiritual life--insisting on the validity of its mental and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: moral conclusions over against the objects of sense. Without this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: insistence no knowledge would progress and be valid. The macrocosm is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mirrored and coloured in a mental and moral microcosm. A replica of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: external world has a reality in consciousness, and this reality is not a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mere photograph of the external, but it is the external as it appears to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the meaning it has obtained in consciousness. The meaning of the world
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is thus something beyond the world itself; it is more than appears at
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: any one moment. If the world were less than this, if the percept could
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: not somehow become a concept, all progress would come to a standstill,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and we should be no more than creatures of sensations and percepts which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: vanished as soon as they appeared. But these do not vanish; they persist
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in various ways, as after-images, concepts, memory. Thus, in the very
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: act of knowing anything at all, something greater than the physical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: object known is present. And Eucken would insist, therefore, that the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mental and spiritual are present from the very beginning and bring to a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mental focus the impressions of the senses. In the interpretation of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eucken's philosophy several writers [p.49] have missed the author's
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: meaning here. They have, through the ambiguity of the term "spiritual"
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in English, conceived of "spiritual life" as something entirely
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: different from the mental life. It is different, but only in the same
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: way as the bud is different from the blossom; it means at the religious
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: level a greater unfolding of a life which has been present at every
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: stage in the history of civilisation and culture.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But, as already noticed, the mental life is passed when we enter the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life of a community. The norms and standards, already referred to, make
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: their appearance and persist in demanding obedience to themselves even
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: at the expense of much within consciousness that points in another
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: direction.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But even such a stage as this does not give satisfaction to man. Much
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: effort and sacrifice are needed to live up to the life of the community.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: And such effort and sacrifice are often the best means of calling into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: activity a still deeper, reserved energy of the soul. The soul now
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: recognises a value beyond the values of culture and civilisation. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Good, the True, and the Beautiful appear as the sole realities by the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: side of which everything that preceded, if taken as complete in itself,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: appears as a great shadow or illusion. Here we are reminded of Eucken's
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: affinity with Plato's Doctrine of Ideas, as well as of his attachment to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the revival of Platonism by Plotinus. Values for life, subsisting in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: themselves, become objects [p.50] of meditation, of "browsing," and of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the deepest activity of the soul. Life is now viewed as consisting in a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: great and constant quest after these religious ideals. It sees its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: meaning beyond and above the range of mentality or even morality, though
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it is well that it should pass as often as possible through the gate of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the former, and is bound to pass always through the gate of the latter.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: A break takes place with the "natural self"; the mental life of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: concepts, though necessary, is now seen as insufficient; and life is now
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: viewed as having a "pearl of great price" before its gaze. Here the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _stirb und werde_ of Paul and Goethe becomes necessary. The real
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: education of man now begins. His life becomes guided and governed by
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: norms whose limits cannot be discovered, and which have never been
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: realised in their wholeness on the face of our earth. What can these
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mean? They cannot be delusions or illusions, for they answer too deep a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: need of the soul to be reduced to that level. If we blot them out of our
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: existence, we sink back to a mere natural or mechanical stage. When the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: soul concentrates its deepest attention on these norms or ideals they
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fascinate it, they draw hidden energies into activity, they give
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: inklings of immortality. Is it not far more conceivable that such a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: vision of meaning, of beauty, and of enchantment is a new kind of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality--cosmic in its nature and eternal in its duration? Man has to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.51] come to a decision concerning this. There is no half-way house
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: here possible without the deepest potencies of human nature suffering
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and failing to transform themselves from bud to blossom and fruit.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: At a later stage in our inquiry this question will recur in connection
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: with the conception of the Godhead. But here it may be observed that to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: decide on the affirmative side that somehow such norms and ideals which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mean so much are cosmic realities, is simply to state no more than that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: an evolutionary process is taking place towards a new kind of world as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: well as a new kind of existence. No outsider is competent to pronounce
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: judgment on the validity of the proofs possessed within this spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: realm. The qualifications here are beyond the range of knowledge,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: although knowledge does not cease to act within such a realm. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: experiences here cannot be measured or weighed; and that a certain
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: obscurity is present in them is only what may be expected, considering
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that the spiritual nature is farther removed from the region of nature
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: with its physical existence than when it deals with problems on the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: intellectual level. But such spiritual proofs are found in the fact that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: these realities present themselves only at the height of spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: development, and in the fact that they produce an _inversion_ of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature of man, and change the centre of gravity of his life to a more
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: inward recess of his being [p.52] than is open on the natural or
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: intellectual side.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Thus, once more, the soul is driven forward by its own necessities to a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religious reality. What can it do but grant cosmic origin and validity
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to such ideals? If these ideals are not this, then, as Eucken points
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: out, they are the most tragic illusions conceivable.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: When they are acknowledged as cosmic realities, man is in the midst of a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion of a _universal_ kind. But the acknowledgment of these as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: cosmic realities is something more than a concept. The men who have come
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to this conclusion required something more than logical arguments in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: order to establish this truth. The conclusions were based upon a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _specific (characteristic)_ religious experience of their own. And such
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a religious experience was larger and more real than anything that could
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be established in the form of concepts concerning it. As we shall notice
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in a later chapter, it is somewhat on this account that Eucken
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: differentiates between _universal_ and _specific (characteristic)_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: It becomes evident that such contents of the new spiritual world cannot
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be utilised by man without effort. These realities have to pass from the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: region of ideas to the region of actual experiences. In other words,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: they must become man's own religion. Man has now become convinced of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality of a universal spiritual life as constituting, in a measure, the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.53] foundation of the evolution of the soul, and as the goal towards
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which he must for ever move. Eucken is unwilling to speculate as to the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: origin or the goal of this. The centre of gravity of life must be laid
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in what may be known and experienced between these two poles. There is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a certainty which is _intermediate_ between man and the Godhead. It is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: when this certainty is realised as an actual portion of the soul that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: man becomes competent to carry farther--backward and forward--the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: implications of this certainty. And implications of a new kind of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _Weltanschauung_ result from the spiritual experiences of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _Lebensanschauung_ of the spiritual life. On this matter we shall touch
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: at a later stage in the inquiry.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: At present let us confine our attention to the _intermediate_ reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which presents itself in a form that is over-individual. It is only when
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: we pass out of the psychology of the subject--a matter that deals with
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the _history_ of mental processes--that we are able to view the meaning
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the realities which are over-individual. As already pointed out,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: these realities are not the creations of man's fancy or imagination
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: after reason has been switched off. They are non-sensuous realities
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which have moulded and shaped the lives of individuals and nations in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: varied degrees. These ideals are not to remain merely objects of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: knowledge; they are to become portions of the inmost experiences of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: soul. This they cannot become without the [p.54] calling out of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deepest energy of the individual. His fragmentary spiritual life--small
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: as it is--still calls for _more_ of its own nature, and this _more_ has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: been seen in the distance as something of infinite value.[11] A
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mountain, as it were, has to be climbed; dark ravines have to be gone
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: through; and rivers have to be swum across. The whole vision means no
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: less than an entrance into _a new kind of world_, the scaling to a new
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: kind of existence, and a conquest which will make the pilgrim a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: participator in that which is Divine. A struggle has to take place,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: because so much that belongs to the life, on the level where it now
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: stands, belongs to a world _below_ it. Impulses and passions, the narrow
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: outlook, the timidity and hollowness of the "small self"--all these,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which have previously remained at the centre of life, have to be thrust
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to the periphery of existence. So that an entrance into the highest
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual world is not merely something to _know_, but far rather
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something to _do_ and to _be_. This is the meaning of Eucken's activism.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: It is not the busying of ourselves over trifles; there is no need of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: encouragement in that direction. It is rather the inward glance on the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature of the over-individual ideals; it is a deep and constant
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: concentration upon their value and significance, in order that the soul
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: may plant itself on the shores of the _over-world_. It is in granting a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.55] higher mode of existence to these ideals, and in preserving them
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: as the possession of the soul, that man finds the ever greater meaning
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of that spiritual life which was present within him from the very
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: beginning of his enterprise. The process of forcing an entrance into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this over-world has to be repeated time after time. There are no enemies
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in front, but the man is surrounded by them from around and behind him.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The indifference, in a large measure of the natural process, the rigid
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: instincts of mere self-preservation, the temptation to smugness and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ease, the cold conclusions of the understanding when satisfied with
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: explanations from the physical world, the hardness of the heart--these
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and many other enemies fight for supremacy, and the soul is often torn
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the struggle. The struggle continues for a great length of time; but
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the history of the world testifies to an innumerable host of individuals
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: who scaled and fell, who started again and again, until at last their
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conceptions of the Highest Good became a permanent experience and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possession of their deepest being.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: And when the spiritual life creates an entrance into this _over-world_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something happens which makes a fundamental difference in the life. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life may again and again sink back to its old level, but what has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: happened will never allow it to remain satisfied on that level. "We fall
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to rise, are baffled to fight better, sleep to wake" (Browning). Life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: now becomes [p.56] alternately _a quest and a fruition_.[12] The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual has to gather his whole energies together because something
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: great is at stake. This is nothing less than the possession of a new
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: kind of reality. The struggle has yielded a conquest for the time being.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: He tastes and "eats his pot of honey on the grave" of enemies within and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: without. This fruition means no less than a taste of "eternal life in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the midst of time" (Harnack), and the relegating of the whole world of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: phenomena to a subsidiary place.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: This is the kernel of Eucken's _Truth of Religion_. The book deals with
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the most subtle psychological problems of the soul, and reaches the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conclusion of an entrance by man into a divine world. All this is far
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: removed from the ordinary traditional conception either of God or of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion. Perhaps the majority of mankind is not as yet ready for such a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: presentation of religion. But I think it may be safely said that it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: through some such mode of conceiving religion as this that the "great
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and good ones" of the world found an entrance into a divine world and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: grasped the conception of the evolution of the soul as a process which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: begins where organic evolution ends.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: CHAPTER III [p.57]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: RELIGION AND NATURAL SCIENCE
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: In the previous chapter we have noticed how man is able to reach an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: over-world which will grant him a new kind of reality over against the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: whole remaining domain of existence. But the evidence hitherto brought
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: forth has been that of the nature of man himself. We have in this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: chapter to inquire whether there is a warrant for such a conclusion
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: within the realm of natural science. Does science give any hint of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: presence of spiritual life anywhere in the universe? Eucken answers
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: distinctly in the affirmative.[13]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The conclusions of natural science have, in modern times, come into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: direct conflict with religion. Traditional religion has grown up on a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: view of the universe which has been [p.58] utterly discarded by modern
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: knowledge. Religious leaders have often had to be dragged to see the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: truth of this statement, and, as Eucken points out, many are still far
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: from realising the seriousness of the cleft between knowledge and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion. The theology of the Middle Ages has not yet disappeared,
