title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: although fortunately there are some signs of a great reconstruction
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: going on in our midst. Fortunately, this naive view of the universe is a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: theology and not a religion; but doubtless even the religion of the soul
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: suffers when its _knowing_ aspect is perpetually contradicted by
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: scientific knowledge. There is such a close connection between "head"
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and "heart"--even closer than between body and mind--that the use of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: discarded theories of the universe and of life cannot but prove
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: injurious to the deepest source of life.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The mental conceptions of religion have, in the course of the ages,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: undergone many transformations, and there is no reason why another
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: transformation should gradually not come about in the present. In Hebrew
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and Greek times we discover a polytheism, after a long course of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: development, emerging into henotheism, and finally, here and there, into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: monotheism. The old conceptions of gods and spirits present in trees and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: wells, mountains and air, are overcome. They are not so much destroyed
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: as supplanted by higher conceptions. In pre-Socratic philosophy we find
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the gods and [p.59] spirits relegated to a secondary place, and Nature
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is conceived as a system of inner energies and strivings. In these
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conceptions Man is drawn closer to Nature, and the connection of his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life is shown to be closely interwoven with the life of Nature. But the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: empirical aspect of this teaching was pushed into the background through
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the teachings of Socrates and Plato. The "myth" regained some of its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: pristine power in a new kind of way; and "God transcendent of the world
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and immanent in the world" came prominently forward as a doctrine of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: universe and of life. This is the kernel of the Christian theology,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: constructed through the blending of Hebrew and Greek philosophies. Such
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a conception remained very largely the philosophy as well as the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: theology of the Christian Church until the seventeenth century. During
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this long interval hardly any progress was made in the investigation of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Nature, so that such a theology proved rather a help than a hindrance to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the religion of those who understood it. But such a theology has been
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: destroyed, however unwilling many people are to acknowledge the fact.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But until this fact is acknowledged, there is very little hope, in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eucken's opinion, of the Christian religion gaining many adherents from
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the side of those who understand the modern meaning and significance of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: natural science. The physical universe has become a problem; and the old
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: solution was a matter [p.60] of speculation based upon scarcely any
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: observation and experiment. Eucken marks the stages which have brought
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: about a revolution in our conceptions of the universe as consisting of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the change brought about in the science of astronomy through Copernicus
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the sixteenth century, the founding of exact science through Galileo
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the seventeenth century, and the theory of evolution propounded by
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Darwin and his followers in the nineteenth century. The whole tendency
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has been to describe and explain Nature in terms of mechanism, and to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: extend such mechanism into the life of man. Proof after proof has poured
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: upon us, and has been the means, on the whole, of establishing a kingdom
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of mechanism within the realm of Nature and of human nature. Theology
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and speculative philosophy went on their courses unheedful of these
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: developments of physical science, until in our day both have had to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reconsider the tenableness of their position, and to see that Nature and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its physical manifestations have to enter as all-important factors into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: their reconstructions. Miracle is now relegated to a secondary place in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: theology, and it has disappeared altogether from science; a Supreme
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Being transcendent of, and immanent in, the world is not known to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: science, however far it reaches into the secrets of Nature. Doubtless
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the loss to religion has been here incalculable; for although the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: natural scientist was able to destroy the old building, [p.61] he was
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: unable to construct a new one. And Eucken shows that the natural
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: scientist will remain unable to accomplish this, because the material
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: with which he deals is physical in its nature and constitutes no more
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: than a part--a secondary part--of what is found in the world.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The old mode of conceiving the universe, when driven from its citadel by
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the new conceptions of physics and astronomy, turned for refuge to the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mystery of Life itself. Here it supposed itself to be safe. But the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: development of modern chemistry and biology shows how dangerous it is to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: base a theological and religious superstructure on the unfilled clefts
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of natural science. The lesson here during the past hundred years ought
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to be a grave warning against its repetition in the future. These clefts
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: have been filled more and more by the investigations and results of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: modern chemistry and biology, so that the theologian is constantly kept
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in a state of panic, and has to shift his camp and run away when the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: tide of knowledge sweeps in with its newly discovered results. The whole
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: situation seems serious, but it is not so disastrous as it appears at
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: first sight. Doubtless the gains of science have been numerous, and have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: shaken and practically ruined the old theological and metaphysical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: foundations; but a halt has now been called on science itself, and its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: limitations have become perceptible even to its own [p.62] leaders. It
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is not quite so certain that the problem of organic life can be settled
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in terms of chemical combinations and mechanism. Many scientists[14] are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: agreed on this point, although they repudiate the claims of neo-vitalists
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: such as Driesch and Reinke.[15] No judgment can be pronounced on this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: subject at the present day, and probably the problem will take a long
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: time before any important results will accrue. And even these results
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: will not solve the problem of organic life, for the manifestations of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life, the higher we mount the scale of being, are not things visible to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the senses but express themselves in the forms of meanings and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: will-relations.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The limits of natural science become clearly perceptible when we enter
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into the complex problem of the relation of subject and object, [p.63]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: or of mind and body. The final tribunal in regard to the great questions
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of life and religion is not natural science. This is not a matter of a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mere wish that it should be so on the part of religious teachers who
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ignore the findings of science, but is a conviction of the scientists
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: themselves.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Natural science has been so busy with the investigation of the physical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world that it has had time to remember but little besides objects in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: external world. And yet what are objects in the external world without
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a subject to know them?[16] And what are the hypotheses which science
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: frames in order to explain phenomena but syntheses of factors framed in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consciousness?[17] What are laws of Nature but mental constructions
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: framed concerning similar ways of behaviour on the part of a large
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: number of objects? What are the fundamental conceptions which serve as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the very groundwork of the whole of science but concepts which are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: explanations of phenomena and not themselves phenomena?[18]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Wherever we look, we find that our view [p.64] of Nature is in the first
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: place a result as well as a conviction of the content of consciousness;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that we do not perceive things and their qualities in a form of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: immediacy, but only after they have entered into consciousness are we
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: able to know what external objects really are. The constructions of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: science in the form of hypotheses and laws are a proof that the reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the physical world and its meaning are known only in so far as they
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: are known by mind, and in so far as the _universal_ (which is a mental
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: content) explains the _particular_ (which may or may not be an object in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the external world).
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eucken emphasises this truth in several of his books, and whenever the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: truth is borne in mind the scientist becomes aware of the existence of a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality beyond that of the objects of sense. And even when the scientist
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is unaware of the mental qualities which operate in perceiving external
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: objects and of the generalisations formed as the result of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: impressions left by the objects in the mind, he uses these all the same.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Professor Haeckel (one of Professor Eucken's colleagues in Jena) starts
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: out in _The Riddle of the Universe_ with the strong hope of reducing the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: whole universe (including God) into a state of material substance, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ends with a kind of peroration on the virtues of the new goddesses, the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: True, the Good, and the Beautiful.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.65] But an increasing number of scientists to-day are aware of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: limits of science. They know that the mental models which they have to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: frame in order to interpret phenomena are not material things, and exist
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nowhere except in a world of mind and meaning. Eucken's conclusion then
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is that what knows and interprets is a mental quality. He would rather
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: call it the life of the spirit of man, or the spiritual life. A
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: non-sensuous power has to operate in order that the physical world may
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be known at all; that power has, further, in a manner unknown, to gather
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the fragmentary impressions of the senses, turn them into that which is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mental, combine them into what is termed meaning.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: We are led back to the point made so clear by Descartes--to his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: insistence on the presence of a thinking subject as the starting-point
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: for the knowledge of all existence. This truth was elucidated later by
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Kant in a manner which the world can probably never get rid of.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Therefore, if so much happens in the mind in connection with the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: knowledge and interpretation of the world, our view of the world _after_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this happens in the mind is entirely different from the view which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: exists _before_ it happens. Thought stands over against the sensuous
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: object, transforms the object into a logical construction of meaning.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: When one becomes aware of this, not only do the objects themselves
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: become most problematic [p.66] in their relation to consciousness, but
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the very tools with which the scientist works--_e.g._ space and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: time--become so puzzling that only by a return to a metaphysic do they
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: become partially explainable. And thus we are landed in a region of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: idealism in the very midst of the work of natural science. Naturalism
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has arisen only because the subject was forgotten in the enchantment of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the object. The attention has been turned so long on the object that the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature and the results of the attention itself are quite left out of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: account. We can all believe in what naturalism has to say concerning
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: organic and inorganic objects; but it has not said enough when it leaves
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the power that knows the meaning of what it says out of account.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The conclusion Eucken arrives at is, then, that we must ascribe reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to the quality that knows and interprets as well as to the thing that is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: known. He ascribes reality to the physical world, but this is not the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: whole of reality. This cannot be so, simply because we could not know
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that the physical world was real had it not been that there was
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: implanted in us a mental organisation to know all this. The other
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality is that of consciousness and the meanings it formulates. Thus
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: natural science itself announces the presence of _more_ than sensuous
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature. This _more_ which knows the external world is the _more_ which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has constructed civilisation, culture, and [p.67] religion. This _more_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has formed an independent inner life over against the natural world. Had
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it not been for this power of the _more_ to construct its inner world,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Life would have been no more than the life of sensuous nature--shifting
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: from point to point, and entirely at the mercy of a physical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: environment. But the progress of mankind shows everywhere the growth of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a life higher in nature than that of physical or animal existence. Some
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: kind of total-life has been formed in which the individual can
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: participate; and in the participation of which he can be carried far
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: beyond physical things and beyond his own individual interests. Mankind
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has striven after truth, and has discovered something that is beyond the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: opinions of individuals, that does not serve his own petty interests,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: but overcomes them and reaches out after truths which are valid and good
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: for all.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: What is all this that has happened? What has brought it about? What is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the individual potency that knows the world and passes beyond it? What
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: are the ideals and norms which revealed themselves in the co-operative
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: movements of humanity, and only revealed themselves when humanity was at
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its highest attainable level? Enough has been said to show that it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _more_ than Nature, that characteristics are found within it entirely
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: unknown in Nature. We are bound to take this _more_ into account, for it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has constructed all the gains of mankind. [p.68] What can it be, in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual efforts of the soul and in the ideal constructions of science
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and the higher ethical and religious constructions of life, but a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality higher than sense and outside the categories of space and time?
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: What better name can be given to it than a Spiritual Life in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: contradistinction to the life of Nature?
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: When this life of the mind and spirit of man is acknowledged, it is seen
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to be the beginning of a new order of existence. There appears within it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a new kind of reality. It is the standpoint from which natural science
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: itself has arisen. Such an acknowledgment of life as a new kind of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality alters in an essential manner the whole view of the world.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Nature now signifies not the whole of things, but only a step beyond
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which the cosmic process progresses. Two worlds, instead of one world,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: now appear--one growing out of the other, but keeping a connection still
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: with the other. Nature consequently gains a deeper significance of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: meaning when we recognise that it gives birth to mind and spirit
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: --characteristics which merge into consciousness, values, and ideals.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Nature is not discarded in our new view, but it takes a secondary place.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The primary place must be given to the spiritual life--the life which is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: active as an organisation in knowing and being and doing. And when this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: truth is realised, this life of mental and spiritual activity becomes
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the [p.69] centre from which the new reality will obtain an ever greater
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: content. The deepest aspect of reality is then discovered, not without
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: but within. This reality is now conceived as something which belongs to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a new kind of world, and this new world stands above the physical world.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Man, when he conceives of things in this manner, will be able to bear
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the indifference of the physical course of existence towards the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual potencies of his being. The natural process may seem to harass
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and even destroy him; it matters not, for he has been led to a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conviction of the possession of qualities which have not come into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: activity and power in any world _below_ him, and which have laws of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: their own and goals spiritual in their nature. But all this will not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: come about as a shower of rain descends. The spiritual life has to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: insist on its superiority to the natural process, and to construct, with
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the deepest energy of its being, ever richer moral and spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: contents for itself; for it is these contents which constitute the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: growth of the meaning and value of the new world, as well as of its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: indestructible reality beyond the process of Nature.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: RELIGION AND HISTORY
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The subject of history has obtained a most prominent position in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: whole of Eucken's philosophy. All his books deal with the subject, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in a manner resembling one another, whatever the particular subject
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: dealt with may be. But the most exhaustive treatment of history
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: presented in his volumes is to to be found in the chapter on history in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _Systematische Philosophie_("Kultur der Gegenwart," Teil I., Abteilung
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: VI.), and in the latter half of _The Truth of Religion_. In the former
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: volume Eucken deals with history in its relation to civilisation and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: culture, and in the latter the place of history in the religions of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world is strikingly expressed.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: We have already noticed in the previous chapter how he set out to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: discover the presence of a mental or spiritual life in the very act of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: knowing the physical world and in the constructions which form both the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: basis and the apex of physical science. It was shown [p.71] here that a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life higher than the physical was present in order to be able to read
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the meaning of the world. Such a life became a standpoint to view
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Nature, and is the possession, more or less, of each individual. But
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: although the possession of individuals and _above_ Nature, the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consciousness that knows Nature is still carried beyond its own
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual life. The meaning of the physical world appears in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consciousness, through the syntheses it forms, as objective, although it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is not an object of sense but of thought; and, further, this very
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: objectivity subsists in the form of generalisations and meanings which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: create standards for each individual in his relations with the physical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world. Eucken then concludes that there is a trans-subjective aspect
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: present in the conclusions of physical science itself.[19] And it is on
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this fact that he bases the presence of a mental or spiritual life in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the very act of knowing at all. But it is evident that the whole of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: man's potencies and relations are not confined to the knowing of Nature
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and framing interpretations concerning it. There are other provinces to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which man is related--other objects besides physical ones to which his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: attention is called to frame interpretations concerning them also.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: History is one of these provinces. The subject-matter here is entirely
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.72] different from the subject-matter of physical science. In the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: latter the objects are physical; in the former the objects are not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: things, but _will-relations._[20] We are in history dealing with the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: effects of heredity and physical environment upon all organic life--man
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: included. But it has been already shown that man, though rooted in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: natural world and dependent upon it, is still the possessor of a world
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which is above the physical. Man's roots in Nature have been unearthed
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in a large measure; and his dependence on the world from which he has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: emerged is greater than was suspected, and probably it will be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: discovered in the future that he is still more dependent on what is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: below him. But however deep his connection with Nature may prove itself
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to be, he will still remain an unsolved problem if he is coolly stripped
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of all the qualities he has gained since he emerged from the bosom of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Nature.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: We are consequently led to the higher aspects of history where the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: centre of gravity of the matter lies in the _relations of wills_.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: By will-relations is meant the impact of individuals upon one another
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: from the side of _meaning_. It is through the expressions of the meaning
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of our concepts that we are able to construct an intelligible world. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual's [p.73] deeper reality does not consist in the percept we
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: obtain of him, but in the mental attitude he has expressed towards a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mental attitude of ours. The _clothing_ of meaning is certainly
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: physical; there is our friend's physical body in front of us, and his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: speech is audible in a physical sense to physical ears. But neither body
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nor speech is absolutely necessary for the expression of meaning to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: another. We have neither seen nor heard many of the individuals who have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: exercised great influence over our lives. Words have answered the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: purpose. By this is not meant that we have not lost something of great
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: value in having to depend on print alone. Something of every individual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reveals itself in his body and speech which is missed when we have to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: depend on paper and ink as mediums of meaning. But meaning is something
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: other than its medium; it is a mental or spiritual content. This content

author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: We thus see that there are presented in such norms two aspects of a very
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: different nature. On the one hand, we discover the contribution of each
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: individual, and witness events dealing with situations which succeed one
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: another with greater or less rapidity. This aspect is in constant flux.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: It constitutes the capability of meeting the needs of the moment. All
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this works well so long as the needs of the moment involve no great
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: complexities. But immediately the situation becomes complex there is a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: turn to something besides this mere flow of things.[21] To what? It is a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: turn to something whose nucleus of meaning and value has persisted in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the midst of all the flow. This is no other than one or other of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: highest of the ideal constructions which formed the basis of the life of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the community. The community had been unconsciously garnering something
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: over-individual and over-historical for its future use. Thus, in history
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: itself there is the presence of a reality higher than the individual,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and higher than the ordinary meaning of the [p.75] hour. This becomes the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: standard by which everything has to be measured. Of course, this norm
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: does not remain static in regard to its own content. But its growth of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: content depends upon the contributions made to it by individuals in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: their will-relations. Something over-individual issues out of all these
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: relations, and this enters into the still higher over-individual norms
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which are the heritage of society. Eucken consequently shows that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: history itself is dependent upon something which works within
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it--interpreting its events, and absorbing into itself something that is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of value. What other can this be but a spiritual life higher not only
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: than physical things but even than the will-relations which accrue from
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: moment to moment? It has already been noticed that on these lower levels
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the spiritual life is ever present--present as a potency and experience
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: when viewed from the standpoint of the individual's creativeness, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: present as norms and values when viewed as an object of thought brought
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: forth through general conclusions founded on situations beyond any
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: single situation of the individual. Thus, we get in Eucken's teaching
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the over-historical as the power which operates within the events of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: history. It is what philosophy has termed the Ideal, and what religion
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has termed the revelation of God. It is not correct, then, to say that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: we are dependent upon the content of the moment apart from the presence
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the [p.76] content of the past in that moment in order to grasp
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality. The Past does not mean a mere series of events which occurred

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: point of its course something other than it was before.[22] But in any
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: At certain epochs in the history of the world great events have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: happened. Often such epochs are followed by epochs of inertia. Men bask
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the sunlight of the glory that was revealed to humanity; they receive
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: help and strength from what had been. But the greater the interval
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: between the occurrence [p.77] of that greatness and the contemplation of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it, the more difficult does it become to grasp and to possess something
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the true meaning, value, and significance of such greatness. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: greatness, as the interval grows, becomes something to be known,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something which is believed to fall upon us in an external, miraculous
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: manner; and finally it often becomes an object of wordy dispute and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: strife. Certain periods in the history of the Christian Church give
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: abundant evidence of the truth of this statement. Eucken points out in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: his _Problem of Human Life_ how barren in creative power, for instance,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: was the fourth century. Why? An interval of nearly three centuries had
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: passed away since the Master and his followers had proclaimed truths and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: experiences which were the burning convictions of their deepest being.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Gradually, and often unconsciously, men glided down an inclined plane,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: until at last the spiritual nucleus of Christianity had largely
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: disappeared and little more than the husks remained. At the close of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: such intervals religion becomes a number of conflicting intellectual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: theories, and the worst passions are called to its support. Dogmatism
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and intolerance prevail, and a blight comes over the choicest potencies
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the soul. All this happens because certain great events and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: experiences of the past are conceived of as marking a terminus in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: history of the moral and spiritual evolution of the world. The [p.78]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: soul is not stirred to its depth to preserve such experiences and, if
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possible, enhance them. Thus the world leaves such a rich spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: content largely behind itself; and when this happens, it becomes a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: matter of the greatest difficulty to recover it. And even when it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: recovered, something of infinite value has been for ever lost. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: present moment of the soul has to live on itself; and such a life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: remains alien to depths of reality which have been plumbed by the great
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual power in the present, that will enable Christianity to be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: lived on such a "grand scale" in the present and the future. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: spiritual experiences of the past have become over-individual and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: over-historical norms for our lives; but such norms are no more than
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: Eucken has worked for many years at this difficult problem--a problem so
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: important in the life of civilisation and religion. It has already been
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: hinted that the conception bears striking resemblances to aspects of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Hegel's philosophy. But there are differences. One of these was pointed
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: out long ago by Eucken: "The gist of religion is with Hegel nothing but
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the absorption of the individual in the universal intellectual process.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Christian type, with purification of the heart, is unintelligible to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: us."[23] Eucken's philosophy, on the other hand, is pre-eminently a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual activism. The life-process is shaped by the collective
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: activity of individuals; and when this activity slackens the ideals of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the over-world suffer. Man is thus called to be what he _ought to be_;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and in the process he heightens something of the value of the Ought. An
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Ought and a Will are involved in the creativeness of the individual life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and of the Life-process; so that it is a mistake to conceive [p.80] of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eucken's activism as some stirring of the individual to realise merely
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: his own needs as these present themselves to him from moment to moment.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the Life-process and a carrier in the making of a new world; but all
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: action are to be ever present. In the light of the vision man becomes
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: value.
