text: external to life; it is to be found in life itself. The reality is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: revealed and, indeed, created by an act of the spirit of man. Such an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: act must be the act of one's [p.136] own deepest being. But although
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: such a new reality is not to be found in anything external to life, yet
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the very revelation points, as we have already observed, to something
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which is over-individual. Even the meaning of the reality itself, from
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its _immanent_ side, is something quite other than the natural life and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its contents. It is something revealed, but not as yet possessed; it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: hard to be reached; and even within the man's own nature obstacles and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: hindrances of various kinds are to be found. But the new reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: persists in the midst of the hindrances; the man discovers himself as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the possessor of a deeper kind of truth than was present and operative
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the ordinary life. A cleavage is therefore made between the "small
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: self" and the spiritual life. In the degree the former wins through the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: calling forth of the deepest activities of the soul, in that degree does
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the transcendent aspect of the new reality urge itself upon man. And
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: when the two aspects--immanent and transcendent--of the reality are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: firmly grasped by the soul, the soul moves upward in the exploration and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possession of its new world.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The failure to enter into this region of religion is due to the fact
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that men often attempt to construct religion on certain so-called
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: faculties of the soul. Some attempt to discover and establish religion
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: through the power and conclusions of the intellect. It is evident that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: when the knowing aspect of consciousness [p.137] takes such a leading
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: part, and deliberately ignores the affective and active aspects, no more
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: than a segment of the reality can be discovered, and such a segment
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: leaves out of account important elements of human nature. If the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: affective aspect takes the lead at the expense of the other two aspects,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: we are here again in a region where only certain fragments of our nature
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: are touched. If the active aspect busies itself without carrying along
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: with itself the content of meaning and value to be discovered in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consciousness, the true element of the greatness of the reality is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: missing. Eucken shows in his _Truth of Religion_ that there must be a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: point in the soul, at some deeper level than any of the three, where the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: three are working conjointly.[48] It must be so, because what is now at
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: stake is more than knowing a thing; it is to _be_ the thing we know we
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _ought to be._ It is unfamiliarity with such a truth that brings a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: difficulty into the mind when face to face [p.138] with the problem of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion. The mind has not learned how to attend to the truth in its own
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: self-subsistence, but posits this truth in its relation to the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conditions in the external world which brought it forth.[49] Thus the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conception of truth is made up very largely of its history on its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: physical side, and this history of the truth comes to possess the entire
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: meaning of the truth itself! The road to religion, in its deepest sense,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is barred to everyone who fails or refuses to grant the deeper reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which presents itself within the soul _a self-subsistence._ The only
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: existence of such a reality can be its own self-subsistence. The reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is now conceived as something quite other than an existence in space; it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: exists for consciousness and can persist within consciousness.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: When reality is conceived as a substance subsisting in itself, the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: passage to the Absolute is opened. This Absolute is the most universal
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and complete meaning and value which the soul is capable of possessing;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its very nature forces itself upon man as being true; and its value has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: revealed itself in its being the only power which will carry farther the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual evolution of the soul. If such an Absolute is left out of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: account, it is evident that the most universal [p.139] truth which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: presents itself to life as absolutely necessary cannot enter into the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deepest recesses of the soul; it cannot be more than a subsidiary
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: element accompanying lower intellectual elements of life, which are more
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: closely allied on such a lower level with physical processes of the body
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and with the physical world. And when truth is treated in this manner,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it cannot possibly make its abode and become a power in the soul.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Consciousness hesitates to create a further cleft within itself because
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the evidence of truth at such a height as this does not lend itself to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the senses. The result is that the full power of the truth fails to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: produce effects on the consciousness, and thus keeps it on practically
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the same level as that on which it has been accustomed to work. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: higher truth--the higher spiritual life--has not become anything more
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: than a fact of knowledge or a probability. It has not become one's own
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life. It is only when this higher aspect of spiritual life becomes
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _one's own life_, and is acknowledged and used, that it is ever possible
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: for man to become the possessor of an original energy, of an independent
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: governing centre, and so to realise himself as a co-carrier of a cosmic
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: movement. This is the presupposition of religion: it testifies that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: within man's soul there appears something higher than sense or
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: intellect, but which remains surrounded by alien elements which impose
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: checks to its further development. It is quite evident that the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: appearance of [p.140] truths which are absolute and complete within the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life is in direct antagonism to much that was previously present within
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it. This fundamental fact, however, is not evident without a great deal
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of attention paid to the nature of the higher elements which present
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: themselves. Without comparing the values of the higher and the lower
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: elements, how is it ever possible to know what they are and what they
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mean? When the whole being attends to both elements--higher and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: lower--there is no possibility of making a mistake concerning the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _different_ values of what are presented. A higher grade of reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reveals itself over against all that had been previously gained. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: soul is forced to admit that something of a higher nature than it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: hitherto possessed seeks admission. And this Higher, if it enters into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the whole of life, so far from revealing itself as a continuation of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: what had already happened, reveals itself as something which is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: discontinuous with the ordinary life, and superior even to the highest
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: attainments of the intellectual life. And it is this aspect which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: produces the conviction of such a revelation as being _objective_ in its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: very nature. It belongs to something or somebody outside our own
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual experience or achievement. That there is much which is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mysterious in all this, is only what might be expected. But the very
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fact that the Higher comes with such power when the soul expects,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: assimilates, and appropriates it [p.141] is a proof of its existence
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: somewhere at the core of the universe. It cannot mean an illusion; it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: brings changes of too fundamental a nature to be no more than that. Its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: very value and the enormous difficulty of turning it from being an idea
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into being a possession demand too much energy of the soul to allow of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its being dismissed without any more ado. It contains elements so
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: different in their nature from the ordinary life of the hour as to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: render it impossible to be considered of no more than of subsidiary
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: importance. For it has to be borne in mind that the values and norms
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: farthest removed from the regions of sense and intellect appear only
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: when man follows the drift of his own higher being; it is not when he
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: remains effortless and satisfied with the life of the hour that such
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: values and norms appear. They appear when the ordinary life is seen
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: through as no more than a stage for the further evolution of the soul
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: through the grasping of a higher kind of reality than has as yet
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: presented itself to it. As Eucken says: "Religion proves itself a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: kingdom of opposites. When it steps out of such opposites, it destroys
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: without a doubt the turbidity and evanescence of ordinary commonplace
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life, and separates clearly the lights and shadows from one another. It
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: sets our life between the sharpest contrasts, and engenders the most
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: powerful feelings and the most mighty movements; it shows the dark abyss
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in our nature, but also [p.142] shows illumined peaks; it opens out
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: infinite tasks, and brings ever to an awakening a new life in its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: movement against the ordinary self. It does not render our existence
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: lighter, but it makes it richer, more eventful, and greater; it enables
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: man to experience cosmic problems within his own soul in order to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: struggle for a new world, and, indeed, in order to gain such a genuine
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world as its own proper life."[50]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: All this is not a matter of speculation, but of fact. And it is in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: recognition of this fact that Eucken's philosophy of religion
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: constitutes a new kind of idealistic movement--a movement tending more
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and more in the direction of Christianity. But he differs here again
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: from the absolute idealists and the pragmatists. The former base their
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Absolute upon the demands of logic, whilst Eucken bases all upon the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: demands and potencies of life; the pragmatists emphasise the primary
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: place of the will in the development of the inner life, but they have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: certainly ignored the presence of over-individual norms, as the goal of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: volition, whilst Eucken holds to the necessity of both. With the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: absolutists the relation of the Absolute with the will is not clearly
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: perceived, and consequently the Absolute becomes merely an object of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: thought and contemplation; and in all this the individual does not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: become aware of a burning desire to move in the direction of the goal.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.143] The pragmatist leaves the individual at the mercy of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: momentary content of consciousness; this content is quite as likely to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be trivial as to be great; and hence there is no absolute standard
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: present to determine the nature and value of this content of the moment,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and consequently no more than a life of effortless drifting can issue
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: out of all this.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: This blend of absolutism and pragmatism is richer in its content than
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: either of the two. Each has missed something of importance, and it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: here supplied by Eucken.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Norms and potency become two indissoluble factors in the evolution of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the higher life. As already stated, the norms have an objectivity of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: their own, and consequently when they enter into life, life becomes
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conscious of their being something _given_ and not brought into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: existence by its own potency. It is out of this conclusion to which life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is forced that the doctrine of Grace, found in some way or other in all
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religions, is to be accounted for. And it is out of the consciousness of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the interval between norm and achievement that the sense of _guilt_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: follows man whenever he penetrates deeply into the deeper experiences of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the soul. Grace and guilt--naming only two experiences of the soul--are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: not remnants of a traditional theology, but essential elements which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: accompany the deepest experience of the soul. When they are wanting, it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is most probable that the soul has not plumbed its own [p.144] existence
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to its very depths, but has rather chosen to be satisfied with what lies
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: but a little way beneath the surface--with what does not cause too much
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: uneasiness, but is sufficient for a life to persist as a good member of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the society by which it is surrounded. Only half a religion can become
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the possession of any individual who does not at least pay as much
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: attention to the nature and value of over-individual norms as he pays to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the nature of the environment and of the ordinary life. It is always a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: sign that humanity is drifting to the shallows of life when it looks
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: upon religion as the flowering of the mere natural life of good custom,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: earthly happiness, and ease. Whenever the tragedy born in the conflict
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: between norms and ordinary life is absent, the very elements which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: constitute greatness and the "taste of eternity" are also absent. It is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: on account of this fact that Eucken insists that no individual or nation
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that loses its own deeper religious experience can be really great or
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: true; for the purest spring of human life and conduct is wanting, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the whole life issues from a shallower stream. It is impossible here to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: enter into the truth of this matter; but our individual observation
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: concerning men and communities is almost enough of itself to verify the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: statement. That such a higher spiritual life is a reality may be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: evidenced further through its effects. It changes the whole relationship
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the man [p.145] who has experienced it to everything he comes in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: contact with. New convictions and new points of view have now actually
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: occurred within his soul; man has become conscious of a spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: inwardness, brought forth through the presence of an over-personal
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual life coupled with his own spiritual needs. With the possession
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of such spiritual elements, how is it possible for him any more to look
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: upon the world and human life with the same eyes as before? The dawning
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of a new reality has made him a new creature; he is now compelled by his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: own deeper nature to preserve and to reflect the light which is within
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: him; and all this brings prominently forward the need of something other
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: for the progress of the world than the first look of things is able to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: show. It is in such manner as this that we must account for all the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ideals which have moved mankind from the level of animalism and greed to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the level of civilisation, culture, morals, and religion. The work is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: far from being completed: the world still clings to the old level of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ordinary life, and is so slow to grasp the value of the life of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual ideals. Still, something has been accomplished in the course
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the ages; and although, probably, the progress has not been
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: continuous, there has been a gain in the "long run." But the point to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: bear in mind is that it is the power of the over-individual ideal which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has carried the race along. Ideals have been perverted, it is true; they
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: have been [p.146] drawn down and mixed with what was inferior in its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature, yet they have never been completely destroyed in this evil
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: process. They have still a marvellous power of disentangling themselves
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: from human perversions, and of revealing themselves once more in their
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: pristine power and glory. "But the spiritual life declares its ability
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: also positively within the human province through a persistent effort to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: move outside the 'given' situation, through a tracing out and a holding
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: forth of ideals, through a longing after a more complete happiness and a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: more complete truth. Why is not man satisfied with the relativity which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: so obstinately clings to his existence? Why has he a longing for the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Absolute in opposition to such relativity, and through this plunges
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: himself into the deepest sorrows and distractions? This has happened not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: only in special situations of individuals, but in the whole process of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: culture; indeed, the upward march of culture would have been impossible
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: without a striving of man from a level above his 'given' position and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: even above himself. Was not subjective satisfaction more easily reached
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: by him in the semi-animal stages of his existence than in culture and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: civilisation with all their toils and tangles, and does the progress of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: culture and civilisation with all their mechanical appliances make him
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the merely human sense happier? What else could compel him to step
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into this perilous track but the necessity of his own nature [p.147]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: revealing to him the presence of a new order of things?"[51]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The whole of this movement is from within without. Even the physical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world has to enter into consciousness before it can be known and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: interpreted; even the over-individual norms have to be accepted and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: interpreted by the spiritual potency before the reality which they
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possess in themselves can become our own personal reality. We receive
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: from without on the plane of Nature and on the planes of mentality and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spirituality. The consciousness does not evolve its content on any level
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of its progress from itself alone. Material from without has to enter
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into it. But the whole of this material will become one's own possession
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the degree it is attended to after it has entered consciousness;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something has to happen to the material _within_ consciousness; it has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to awaken a potency, and has to distil its own content within that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: potency. But as this potency is not of the same nature entirely as what
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: presents itself as possessing value, it is clear that the higher element
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which presents itself has to enter into a struggle for the throne of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life with elements of a lower order. As this all-important fact has been
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: dealt with in a previous chapter, there is no need to dwell on it again;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: but it is well to bear in mind that the fact [p.148] constitutes an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: important element in Eucken's conception of "universal" religion.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: "Universal" and "Characteristic" religion do not constitute two
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: different religions, but two grades of the one religion. In "Universal"
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion Eucken deals very largely with the intellectual grounds of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion. He is aware that it is necessary for us to carry our whole
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: potencies into religion. Intellect is one of these, and we cannot afford
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to construct our religion on what comes into perpetual conflict with
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: intellectual conceptions. Eucken has shown that intellectual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conclusions, if they are carried far enough and include the whole of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: their own meaning, lead us into religion. We have already noticed how
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the presence of norms and standards were necessitated by the very theory
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of knowledge itself. It is a great gain for man to know that this is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: so--that in so far as knowledge testifies anything in regard to religion
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and spiritual life it affirms more than it negates. It is of enormous
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: advantage to be assured that knowledge is on our side in the quest for
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something that is deeper than itself.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Further, Eucken conceives it as the function of religion on this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: "Universal" level to present, on the other hand, the actual situation.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: What but knowledge can reveal to us the difference between spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: norms and ordinary life, between intellect working alone and intellect
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: merged with the spiritual potency of one's [p.149] being? We are bound
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to know these and a hundred other things. They all go to prove that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: there is justification for the movement of spiritual life in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: direction of an over-world, and in its hope for the possession of a new
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: grade of reality. It is well and necessary to affirm all this before we
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: enter on the "grand enterprise." When an affirmation, based upon
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: insight, is made, there will be present within the soul a greater power
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to resist hunting after shadows or slipping to a lower level when we are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the very midst of the quest. And, indeed, on this very level of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: "Universal" religion something besides the mere knowledge of religion
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has taken place. Values which are intellectually true are bound to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: exercise some influence on the life. Thus, something of the nature of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the higher reality has touched the soul and will of man. We _know_ in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: what we have believed. This is a stage which must be passed through, for
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: we can never feel certain upon a higher altitude unless we are certain
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of what had led to it. And although, on the higher altitude, there is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the merging of intellectual truth in something higher than itself, still
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: what is discovered on this higher level is richer in content if we can
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: call up at times intellectual affirmations for its support.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But "Universal" religion has its limitations, and has to pass into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something more characteristic, specific, and personal. The over-personal
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: norms, which are spiritual in their very nature, [p.150] have not only
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to be interpreted, they have also to be appreciated and reverenced. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _How_ of their appearance, after it is settled, takes a secondary place,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and the norms in their own value and subsistence are attended to. Thus,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: they become not merely ideas having some kind of reality of their own,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: but also become revelations of the very nature of the world; they become
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the source of all creation; the one spring of all being. In other words,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: they are made to mean the Godhead; they mean the creation and sustaining
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: power of all life. A communion with the Godhead now takes place, and man
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: finds himself in possession of experiences brought about without the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: intervention of the world. Thus "Universal" religion culminates in a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: "Characteristic" or personal religion. And to this culmination, as it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: presented by Eucken, we now turn.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: CHAPTER IX [p.151]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: CHARACTERISTIC RELIGION
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: On the level of "Universal" religion great changes have taken place in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life. The consciousness and conviction of the reality of a new kind of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world have arisen; the sensuous, and even partially the intellectual,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: domains have been relegated to a secondary place: other values, higher
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in their nature and more universal in their scope, have attracted the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: attention of mind and soul. In all this a change has taken place in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: disposition as well as in the will. Prior to this change the character
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: had not become conscious of its own inwardness, but remained subservient
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to the norms of social and moral inheritance. Some amount of morality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and good will have issued forth in this manner, and, indeed, the gain
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: cannot be overestimated. But it is evident that something further has to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: happen if the movement of society is to proceed onward and upward, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: if the energy for such a movement is to be discovered within the soul.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The whole material which enters into consciousness has to obtain a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deeper meaning [p.152] than it hitherto possessed. And this happens on
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the level of "Universal" religion. The _spiritual_ is now recognised as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the highest manifestation of life; and this spiritual is seen to be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something which has to be gained through a struggle which calls the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: whole nature into activity. Such a movement from the less to the more
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual proceeds side by side with the _freedom_ of the individual.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Freedom has now taken a new meaning. Hitherto it meant little more than
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the consciousness of the individual moving along the line of least
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: resistance. The effort to move in such a direction is generally
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: pleasurable; and when it tends to become painful the individual gives up
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the effort. The highest norms were not present with a categorical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: affirmation of their reality and value. But when they are present, the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: will is turned from the direction of ordinary life and its ease to the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conception of the meaning and value of the highest norms. Something,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: appearing as of intrinsic value, now makes itself felt, and stirs the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: whole nature. Thus, a _new movement_ begins; the _passive_ attitude of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the soul gives way to an _autonomous_ attitude and movement. The will,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consequently, is conscious of a deeper need than any hitherto
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: experienced, and therefore calls into being some deeper elements of its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: own in order to reach its goal. The whole nature has now affirmed the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _idea of the good_, which had dawned upon it as an imperative. It is in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.153] such a moment that the real nature becomes free--it becomes
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conscious, through and through, of the possibility of leaving its old
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world and of ascending into a new one. This is, in Eucken's words, the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: real spiritual evolution (_Wesensbildung_) of human nature. This
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: evolution, which, prior to this, was considered very largely as a kind
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of gift of the environment, is now perceived as capable of realisation
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: only in so far as the spiritual norms are willed. When we examine the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: progress of humanity, we discover that it has taken place in this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: manner; a task had to be set and the whole nature had to be called forth
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to realise it. The result is that a new creation takes place in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: history of the world. Such a creation becomes a new norm in the moral
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world, as well as a possession in the life of the individual who has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: struggled to realise it.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Such a spiritual process, after something of its nature has been
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: realised, finds necessities laid upon it on all hands. Once we have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: stepped into the very centre of spiritual norms and ideals they begin to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reveal with a wonderful rapidity and impressiveness their own intrinsic
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: content and value. "Universal" religion has enabled us to realise that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: we are dealing with "grounds" which are a demand of the deepest nature,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and with convictions which seem, without a doubt, "to ring true." The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: man has found a shelter in the midst of all the chaos and welter of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: natural process, [p.154] and his deepest reason has not failed to come
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to the assistance of his spiritual need. He now becomes conscious of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: security and even of victory in the enterprise before the battle has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: really begun on an arena outside his own nature; a conviction is being
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: brought into being within his deepest soul that the best and strongest
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: elements in the universe are on his side. Although hindrances and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: entanglements of all kinds increase in number, the increase in spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: certainty, and faith in the final issue of his life, have grown at a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: greater ratio. Such a man has settled his destiny; he has come to the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: great spiritual affirmation of life--an affirmation which has to be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: repeated so often, and which each time distils something of a higher
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: order within the soul.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: It is evident that such an affirmation of the reality of spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ideals, which have now an existence of their own, should lead us
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: farther. If they mean so much, why cannot they mean more? If they
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: subsist in themselves, they must be what they _are_. They are to us
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: meaning and value of infinite significance. But such and other spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: characteristics are _not things_, and, as we have seen, not mere
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: projections of our own individual selves. There is nothing short of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: personality and over-personality by which they can be even partially
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: designated and determined. We are forced to this conclusion if they are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to be objects of communion and union: and we are forced [p.155] further
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to gather the Many into the One. That was what was done on all lower
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: planes. Why stop short here, because infinitely much happens when the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Many find their points of union and meaning in the One?[52] We have said
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that infinitely much happens when the Many find their meaning in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: One. A need of the nature has arisen which demands this, and it has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: arisen at its _highest possible level alone_. Such a nature will never
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: become absolutely certain of the meaning and value of all that has led
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: up to this until the One obtains a self-subsistence. If this effort
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fails, the whole effort of development towards unity and inwardness
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fails. And when such a chain of effort snaps at its highest link of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual development, everything that had entered into the process at
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: all the levels below it snaps along with it in so far as it had any
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: validity whatever in the light of what is higher than itself.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But the fact that this conception of the One, conceived as Absolute
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Spiritual Life, has produced so many effects of the highest kind is a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: proof of its existence. Qualities come into being which can never come
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: with such power in any other way. The spiritual experiences, revealed at
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: such a level, have something to say on this matter. These experiences,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.156] although aware of the meaning of universal concepts, have become
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: aware of something higher still: Knowledge has given place to Love; a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: region has been reached beyond all the contradictions of the world and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: beyond all the dialectics of knowledge. It is a region which includes
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the good of all without injuring the good of any; and all the meaning of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the world and of life is interpreted from this highest standpoint. This
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is the essence of "characteristic "or specific religion. On the level of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: "universal" religion, God was seen from the standpoint of the world; in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: standpoint. All must now be viewed and valued from the standpoint of

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: towards the "holy of holies" of the One; they descended into the plains
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: to reveal what they had seen and heard and experienced on the heights.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: [p.157] religion to the higher stage of "characteristic," men have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: discovered a further security and spiritual evolution of their whole
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: being. Their views of man and the world have become changed; they now
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: to them a peace and a power which are far beyond all the lower unities.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: highest citadel of religion and keep open the avenues to Infinity,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this, the better for the world and for the individual. But a taste of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this Infinite Love can be obtained without all this. Just as some of us
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: are able to walk without a knowledge of the bodily mechanism and to eat

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: amount of satisfaction by resting upon and trusting in a Love Absolute,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the distractions of the world and of knowledge. He cannot remain here
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: for any great length of time; he has to return to the world, but he is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: never [p.158] again the same being after having scaled the "mount of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: transfiguration." "Religion holds as certain and conclusive that this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: new inner foundation is the greatest thing of all and the wonder of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: overcoming of the old world and the creation of a new one; it is on
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: account of this that religion longs for the conviction of the whole man,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and brands the denial of this as pettiness and unbelief. The world may
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: therefore remain to the external view as it appeared before--a kingdom
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of opposition and darkness; its hindrances within and without may seem
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world, everything is transformed from within, and the clearness of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: light appears all the more by contrast with all the depth of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: darkness. Indeed, in the midst of all the mysteries of existence, hope
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and conviction and certainty will consolidate our experience, so that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ultimately evil itself must serve the development of the good."[53] Or
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the words of Luther: "This is the spiritual power which reigns and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: rules in the midst of enemies, and is powerful in the midst [p.159] of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: my salvation."[54]
