text: have already touched on this aspect of the impossibility of obtaining
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: sufficient strength for the warfare of the present in anything that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: occurred in the past. Some measure of strength--and no psychology is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: able to say how much--can be obtained from a vision of the spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: meaning and significance of the life of the Founder. But there is very
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: great danger in looking here alone for the sole source of all the help
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: we need. The spiritual principles of Christianity have been operating in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the world ever since the Master presented the Gospel which he lived and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: died for. The problem of Christianity is thus a twofold problem. On the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: one hand, we have constantly to go back to the Fountain-head, because it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is here that the stream is purest. But we have, on the other hand, to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: enter into the religious current which surrounds us; and this may be not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: so [p.183] pure as it was at its source. Alien waters have entered into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the current--waters of very different taste from those which even the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Founder expected. These have doubtless polluted the stream. But, on the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: other hand, good elements--primary and secondary--have entered into the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deepest nature of Christianity itself. These have to be taken into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: account. They have been necessitated by the new and ever more complex
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: situations and conditions into which Christianity has had to enter from
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: generation to generation. It was comparatively easy for Christianity in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its early beginnings to include within its compass the whole of life.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But by to-day life has branched off in so many new directions;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: perplexing problems of knowledge and life have made their appearance. We
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: dare not dismiss these to a region outside the sphere of influence of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Christianity. Christianity, if it is to remain and increase as a living
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: force, has to interpret these problems; it has to help us to distinguish
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: between the chaff and the wheat.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: What, then, is the true meaning of Christianity? Eucken shows that it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: not possible to determine the nature of Christianity without realising
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that the nucleus common to all religions lies in the fact "that they
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: manifest and represent a Divine Life, and that such a Life in its inmost
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: foundation is superior to its external configuration and activity, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is able to withstand all the changes of time, and to [p.184] maintain
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: within itself, in spite of all its curtailment through the human
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: situation, _an eternal truth_." This nucleus lies deeper in Christianity
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: than in any other religion. But even Christianity itself is not a pure
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual nucleus. Much, as we have already noticed, has gathered around
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it--much that reveals a lower grade of spirituality. All this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: constitutes the clothing of Christianity. The clothing has been changed
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: again and again in the past. What reason is there for affirming that it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: cannot be changed again? It is therefore necessary to differentiate
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: between the _Substance_ of Christianity and its _Existential-form_. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Substance constitutes the fundamental Life superior to the world, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has been present throughout the whole of the Christian era; and it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this Substance which has raised men beyond the merely human situation;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it is the Substance that has enabled men to overcome the world, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: afterwards to see the world from the standpoint of the Divine. In this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: work of differentiation we are dependent in a very large measure upon
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the results of knowledge. Such results do not grant us the Substance of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Christianity, because this is something which has to be lived into in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: order to be possessed. The transformation which occurs on account of a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: change in the Existential-form may indeed prove helpful to the spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nucleus itself, because it represents a truth of the intellect-a truth
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which does not conflict with any [p.185] knowledge outside its own
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: sphere. There are many dangers to be discovered in this process of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: interpreting the spiritual nucleus. A mode of interpretation whose
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: meaning has very largely passed away is bound to prove injurious,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: because it comes into sharp conflict with a newer and more comprehensive
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: meaning, and consequently Christianity fails to win the support of those
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: who are acquainted with the new Existential-form. And even the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual who retains the old clothing, and looks upon it as being
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something of the same nature as the spiritual nucleus, is in danger of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: basing a portion of his religion on a foundation of sand. But, on the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: other hand, he who is aware of the flaws of the old Existential-form
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: without having assimilated the Spiritual Substance which lies beneath
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it, is in danger of drifting from religion altogether. The only way of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: serving best and carrying farther the development of the Christian
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion is to grasp and experience deeply the fact that the Spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Substance is something entirely different from its form of existence.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Its form of existence is an attempt to account for the Substance; it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consists of intellectual concepts. And as with everything else in this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world so with religion; mere intellectual concepts change, and cannot be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: more than receptacles used by the human mind to enshrine the things
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which are presented as meanings and values within the soul.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.186] Eucken pays great attention to the necessity of this process of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: differentiation between the two elements in Christianity. There is a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: need to-day of a new form of existence for Christianity; but the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: satisfaction of this need will not grant us the spiritual nucleus
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: itself. The spiritual nucleus is something to be gained not by means of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: knowledge, but by means of love. Eucken goes so far as to state that the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: idea of love and love of one's enemy as presented in Christianity forms
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a new element for the redemption of the individual and of the race. To
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: grasp this idea and to penetrate into its nature is to solve all the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: problems of life and death. This is the Eternal element in the Christian
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion. It is found, it is true, in other religions; but why should we
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: look for it elsewhere when it blossomed with such divine glory in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life of the Founder? This is the highest spiritual synthesis
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conceivable. The world has known nothing greater, and nothing greater is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to be known. This is the Eternal element in Christianity which has to be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possessed and preserved and furthered. If we ask the question concerning
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the success or failure of Christianity in the future, the answer is to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be found by answering the question, Is Love to God and Love to man found
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: within it to-day? If we are able to answer in the affirmative, we are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: thereby answering the question in regard to the future duration and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conquests of Christianity. And if it possesses [p.187] this element
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deeply enough, it can adopt any existential-form which appears true
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: without any kind of alarm. If we have to answer in the negative, there
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is no guarantee as to persistence of Christianity in the future.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Anything less than the spiritual nucleus of Love is lacking in strength
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: necessary to withstand the storms of the future.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: We thus see that the essence of Christianity and its durability do not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: lie in any kind of theology: it lies within the Spiritual Substance
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which has abode within it throughout the centuries. Here will the world
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: find its peace and power; here will all social complexities be solved;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: here will the meanings and blessings of the spiritual over-world of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: goodness and love become the possession of man. This is what Eucken
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: means by contending that it is not the business of Christianity to deal
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: with social problems in any light but the light of Infinite Love.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Without an experience of this deepest source of Christianity, we do not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possess the equipment for doing anything more than patching and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: re-patching the evils of the world. And all our patching, when but a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: small span of time has passed away, will leave the situation just as it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: was, or probably worse. Every solution will give birth to a new
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: complexity; the world may be incessantly active in connection with the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: betterment of the social situation,'but we shall never heal the wounds
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of individuals and of nations until they are [p.188] brought to the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: depth of the spiritual life revealed in Christianity as Eternal Love. "A
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: warm love towards all humanity runs through Christianity; it longs to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: redeem every individual; it gives man a value beyond all special
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: achievements and on the other side of all mental and moral deeds; it has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: been the first to bring the pure inwardness of the soul to a clear
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: expression. But it has also, through the linking of the human to a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Divine and Eternal Order, raised life beyond all that is trivial and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: merely human with its civic ordinances and social interests. He who,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: with the best intention, views Christianity as a mere means for the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: betterment of the social situation, draws it from the heights of its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature, and deprives it of the main constituent of its greatness--the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: emancipation from the petty-human within the depths of the human itself.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: It is essentially the nature of Christianity that it transplants man
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into a new world over against the world that is nearest to our hands; it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has planted the fundamental conviction of Platonism of the existence of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: an Eternal Order over against the world of Time amongst a great portion
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the human race, and has given a mighty impetus to all effort. But it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has, though it separated the Eternal from Time, brought it back again
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into Time; and through the presence of the Eternal it has, for the first
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: time, proposed to mankind and to each individual a fundamental inner
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: renewal, [p.189] and through this has inaugurated a genuine
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: history."[63]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Acknowledging such a nucleus as constituting the very substance of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Christianity, Eucken proceeds to show the necessity of preserving and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: unfolding the nucleus against the changes of Time. The nucleus has to be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: preserved over against Nature. It has been noticed in previous chapters
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: how modern science has presented us with a view of Nature immensely
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: vaster than that presented in Christian theology. Such a view has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: destroyed for ever a large number of the theological conceptions of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: past. The earth has been reduced to a subsidiary place within the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: cosmos; and any attempt to return to the old conceptions is bought at
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: too high a price. A new mode of thought in regard to the interpretation
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: conceptions of life and existence. There is no longer any meaning in

author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: asking whether the Founder was a "mere man" or a God. He was an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: intermediate reality between the two. To measure the depth and content
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of his soul is a presumption of shallow minds; to determine in a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: speculative manner the exact nature of his divinity, and to formulate
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: imposing doctrines out of all this is quite as presumptuous. It is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: sufficient for us to know that he overcame the world, that the Godhead
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: dwelt in a form of immediacy within his soul. All this is an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: experimental proof of the working of the Divine upon the plane of Time.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But such Divine breaks in pieces if it is subjected to exact
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: determinations. Some account of it we must have: the understanding
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: demands this; but that account must include what the best light of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: knowledge has to throw on the subject. But when all is said, something
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: infinitely greater remains unsaid, and yet to be experienced--something
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that requires the soul to exert itself in order to experience what all
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this means. When face to face with the meaning and value of the life and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: death and spiritual resurrection [p.199] of the Founder of our
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Christianity, we are face to face with an eternal reality revealed
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: within the soul of the "son of man." At such a depth of our nature, the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: petty questions concerning how much or how little was present disappear
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into the background of life, and we are able through such a vision to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: pass to the Father. When emphasis is laid on such a fact as this,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Christianity will again become a religion of the spirit--a religion
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which will unite all mankind at a point of unity beneath all close
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: intellectual determinations and differences. And Eucken points out that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it is not in the life of Jesus alone that we can obtain such a vision.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But we do not gain the vision by merely _saying_ this. If we know of any
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: other character who _was_ so much and who _did_ so much, probably we
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: shall obtain there what we need. But in the Western world at least we do
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _not_ know any such character; the essence of his life and personality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has been always connected with the conception of God. But this is not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the sole conception and, as Eucken says, we cannot bind ourselves
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: entirely to this one point in Christianity. The narrow paths which lead
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to religion are many; we have to draw help from all quarters where the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Divine has been revealed. But the danger lies in merely knowing so many
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: such paths while walking on none of them. The personality of Jesus will
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: remain in Christianity, and the world in its darkness will turn again
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and [p.200] again to that palpable proof of the Divine seen on such a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: summit, and endeavour to scale the same everlasting hill of God. "Here
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: we find a human life of the most homely and simple kind, passed in a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: remote corner of the world, little heeded by his contemporaries, and,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: after a short blossoming life, cruelly put to death. And yet, this life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: had an energy of spirit which filled it to the brim; it had a Standard
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which has transformed human existence to its very root; it has made
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: inadequate what hitherto seemed to bring entire happiness; it has set
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: limits to all petty natural culture; it has stamped as frivolity, not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: only all absorption in the mere pleasures of life, but has also reduced
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the whole prior circle of man to the mere world of sense. Such a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: valuation holds us fast and refuses to be weakened by us when all the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: dogmas and usages of the Church are detected as merely human
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: organisations. That life of Jesus establishes evermore a tribunal over
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the world; and the majesty of such an effective bar of judgment
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: supersedes all the development of external power."[68]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: We may bring this chapter to a close by once more pointing out Eucken's
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: insistence on the Spiritual Substance of Christianity and the need of a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: new Existential-form. The Substance was present in the life of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Founder; mankind has to turn to that fact for one of [p.201] the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: experimental proofs of the Divine. But such a fact is not sufficient. It
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is something which happened in _someone else_, and not in ourselves. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fact is to serve as an inspiration that something similar shall and can
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: happen _in ourselves_. When this is realised, we become conscious of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: power of the Divine within the soul; and the problems of our own day are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: seen and interpreted in the same spirit as that in which Jesus faced and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: interpreted the problems of his day. Such a spiritual experience will
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: become a power to use all the good of life, and thus sanctify it in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: very using of it. The over-personal norms and standards have now become
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: our own possession; they enable us to see the world as it ought to be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: seen and to work for the realisation of the vision; and the norms mean
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: even more than this, for we have already seen that they point to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something _beyond_ themselves and yet continuous with themselves. They
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: point to Infinite Love as the very essence of the Godhead. The reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the over-individual norms and the conception of the Divine as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Infinite Love thus induce in us a conviction of the possibility of an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: evolution of the spirit and of a reality beyond sense and time. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eternal thus enters into Time and overcomes Time. This is Eucken's final
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conclusion in regard to the Christian religion and the destiny of man.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But all this has to be experienced before it [p.202] can be realised.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: "The task to-day is to work energetically, to labour with a free mind
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and a joyful courage, so that the Eternal may not lose its efficient
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: power by our rigid clinging to temporal and antiquated forms, so that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: what we have recognised as human may not bar the way to the Divine as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that Divine is revealed in our own day. The conditions of the present
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: time afford the strongest motives for such work. For once again, in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spite of all the contradictions which appear on the surface of things,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the religious problem rises up mightily from the depth of life; from day
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to day it moves minds more and more; it induces endeavour and kindles
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the spirit of man. It becomes ever plainer to all who are willing to see
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that mere secular culture is empty and vain, and is powerless to grant
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life any real content or fill it with genuine love. Man and humanity are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: pressed ever more forcibly forward into a struggle for the meaning of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life and the deliverance of the spiritual self. But the great tasks must
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be handled with a greatness of spirit, and such a spirit demands
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: freedom--freedom in the service of truth and truthfulness. Let us
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: therefore work together, let us work unceasingly with all our strength
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: as long as the day lasts, in the conviction that 'he who wishes to cling
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to the Old that ages not must leave behind him the old that ages'
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: (_Runeberg_), and that an Eternal of the real kind cannot [p.203] be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: lost in the flux of Time, because it overcomes Time by entering into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eucken is aware of the various Life-systems which present themselves on
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: every side as all-inclusive. But he sees no hope for a real spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: education of mankind until every Life-system shall seek for a depth
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: beyond the _natural_ man and all his wants. And such a movement is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: visible amongst us to-day. It needs to be possessed and proclaimed. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: redemption of the world depends upon its success. The Christian religion
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is such a Gospel. "But a movement towards a more essential and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: soul-stirring culture--to a progressive superiority of a complete life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: beyond all individual activities--cannot arise without bringing the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: problem of religion once more to the foreground. Our life is not able to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: find its bearings within this deep or to gather its treasures into a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Whole unless it realises how many acute opposites it carries within
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: itself. Life will either be torn in pieces by these opposites, or it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: must somehow be raised above them all. It is the latter alone that can
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: bring about a thorough transformation of our first and shallow view of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the universe as well as the inauguration of a new reality. Man has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: emerged out of the darkness of nature and remains afflicted with the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: afflictions of nature; yet at the same time, with his appearance upon
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the earth the darkness begins to illumine, and [p.204] 'nature kindles
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: within him a light' (Schopenhauer); he who is a mere speck on the face
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of a boundless expanse can yet aspire to a participation in the whole of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Infinity; he who stands in the midst of the flux of time yet possesses
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: an aspiration after infinite truth; he who forms but a mere piece of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature constructs at the same time a new world within the spiritual life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: over against it all; he who finds himself confined by contradictions of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: all kinds, which immediate existence in no way can solve, yet struggles
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: after a further depth of reality and after the 'narrow gate' which opens
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into religion. Through and beyond all the particular problems of life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and the world, it behoves us to raise the spiritual life to a level of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: full independence, to make it simultaneously superior to man as an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual and to bring it back into his soul. When this comes to be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: there is at the same time a transformation of his inmost being, and for
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the first time he becomes capable of genuine greatness.... These final
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conclusions strengthen the aspiration after a religion of the spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life.... Such a religion is in no way new, and Christianity has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: proclaimed it and clung to it from the very beginning. But it has been
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: interwoven with traditional forms which are now seen through by so many
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: as pictorial ideas of epochs and times. Earlier times could allow the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Essence and the Form to coalesce without discovering any incongruity in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this. But the [p.205] time for doing this has irrevocably passed away.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The human which once seemed to bring the Spiritual and Divine so near to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: man has now become a burden and a hindrance to him. A keener analysis, a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: more independent development of the Spiritual and Divine, and, along
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: with this, the truth of religion, do not succeed in reaching their full
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: effects if religion is looked upon as merely something to protect
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individuals, instead of as that which furthers the whole of humanity

author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: --as that which is not merely a succour in times of trouble and sorrow
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: but also as that which guarantees an enhancement in work and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: creativeness. The situation is difficult and full of dangers, and small
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the meantime is the number of those who grasp it in a deep and free
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: sense, and who yet are determined to penetrate victoriously into it, so
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: that the inner necessities of the spiritual life may awaken within the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: soul of man. Whatever new tasks and difficulties lie in the lap of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: future, to-day it behoves us before all else to proceed a step upward in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the direction of the summits and to draw new energies and depths of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual life into the domain of man; for this kind of work will

text: prevent the coming of an 'old age' upon humanity and will breathe into

text: its soul the gift of Eternal Youth."[70]
