text: of various Life-systems, of their struggle with one another, and of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: necessity for a religious synthesis which will include their most
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: important results within itself.[71] The answer as to the possibility
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and necessity of such a synthesis constitutes the kernel of Eucken's
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Philosophy of Religion. He has succeeded in a remarkable manner in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: assessing the results of science, philosophy, sociology, art, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religion. In them all he has discovered the presence of a reality which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is non-sensuous in its nature, and, which reveals itself [p.207] in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: judgments of value that carry within themselves their own _necessity_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and _self-subsistence_. This is his conclusion in regard to the work of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the spirit of man on whatever plane of knowledge or experience that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spirit works. Man's spirit has to carry all its knowledge and experience
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into its own conative spiritual potencies. We thus see that everything
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: becomes an aid to the unfolding of an ever greater degree of reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: within the spirit of man. It is then within the _spirit_ of man that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: everything finds its interpretation and value. Whatever interpretation
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is given to anything apart from the union of the _whole_ potency and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: cognition of man's spirit is only a partial interpretation. And it is in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the failure to recognise this truth that so many Life-systems have set
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: themselves against the higher aspects of philosophy and religion. The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: most important question has not been asked: What is the relation and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: value of all results in connection with the deepest potency and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: necessity of man's spirit? Are these results capable of enriching that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spirit of man when he becomes conscious of them? These are the questions
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which Eucken continually asks and answers in his great works; and it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this fact which makes his teaching so valuable and superior to all the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Life-systems of our day. It is difficult to think of any aspect of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: experience which Eucken has left out of account. He has not, indeed,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: interpreted [p.208] in detail all the Life-systems in vogue, and no
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: human being is capable of achieving such a task; but he has clearly
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: perceived the flaws which lie in them all. And this discovery of his has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: revealed a flaw common to them all. That flaw consists in ignoring the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: presence of a spiritual life as the great workshop where every form of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality finds its truest meaning. This flaw is so serious in that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: several Life-systems have thus over-estimated the importance of their
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: results by neglecting to take into account the potentialities and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: necessities of man's spirit. Let us, then, try to trace this defect in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: connection with some of the most important Life-systems in vogue to-day.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: When the various systems of _Idealism_ are estimated, they seem to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: present aspects of reality with vast portions of human potencies and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: experiences left out of account. _Absolute Idealism_ is based upon the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: demands and implications of logic. Its doctrines would have taken a very
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: different colouring had it considered that the necessities of Logic have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to be adjusted to the necessities of Life. Such systems are of little
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: value to the soul, because the needs of the soul were not taken into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: account when they were formulated. This fact was the main cause of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: late Professor James's rebellion against all forms of Absolute Idealism.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: He felt that they bore no relationship to human life and its needs, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consequently could not exercise any important [p.209] influence on life;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: they could not move the will, for no possibility of reaching the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Absolute was offered to man. All the conclusions were in the realm of an
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _intellectual universal_ and not in the realm of _spirit_. They must be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: unreal in the highest sense on account of this very failure. They have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: presented their half-gods as realities outside Nature, human nature, the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: pressing ideals of life, and even God Himself.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eucken shows that any true Life-system has to start with Life itself.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: There may be interpretations needful which have no implications for
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Life, and these have a right of their own; but when such interpretations
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: are carried further, when the subject who _knows_ such interpretations
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and who _uses_ them is taken into account, then the interpretations
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: found on this level are something quite different from what they were
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: when the whole spirit of man was not taken into account. Eucken
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consequently comes to the conclusion that philosophy has not completely
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fulfilled its vocation until it has become a philosophy of _Life_--until
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the truest meaning of every object is discovered in its relation to all
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the necessities of the spirit. And it is here that his teaching comes
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: into conflict with so much that goes by the name of Idealism. How can
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: any system be more than a half-truth when its final meaning is presented
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: with but little attention to the highest aspect we know in the world
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: --to human life in its struggles and conquests, [p.210] in its living
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and loving, and its forward movement towards some distant goal? The
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: special value of Eucken's teaching lies, then, in the fact that it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: interprets what happens, can happen, and ought to happen within life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: itself. No system which leaves out the soul with its possibilities is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: complete. This has been done too often in the past, and is being done
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to-day. Is it, then, a wonder that philosophy has given so very little
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: help to Life in its complex problems without and its sharp opposites and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: contradictions within? Life is more and needs more than a philosophy of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: words, devoid of power, can offer it. Life, when at its best, believes
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the all-power of its own spiritual potency; it has faith in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possibility of ascent from height to height, as well as in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possibility of an incessant progress not only of individuals but of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: whole of mankind.[72] A System stands or falls according as it is able
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to conceive of Life in such a manner. And Eucken has done this as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: probably no other living philosopher has done it.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: If we turn to _Immanent Idealism_, we discover the same failure. It
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: emphasises the presence within consciousness of what is idealistic and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: noble, but it leaves out the objective and imperative character of what
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is present. It also forgets that the possession of ideals as ideas is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: only the initial stage of such ideals becoming a very portion [p.211] of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the deepest substance of soul itself. We may deceive ourselves even with
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the contemplation of the best ideals; they can never become truly ours
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: until the will is set in motion and the whole nature is stirred to its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: depths in order to press forward to what it perceives as having infinite
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: value. Something has inevitably to happen within the depth of the soul
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: before its real creation can advance. Eucken here, again, has perceived
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: this truth and presents it everywhere with great power. His Philosophy
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is an _Activism_ of the most powerful type. He is aware that to _know_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and to _be_ are so far apart. But his Activism is not a mere movement of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the individual's will, brought forth by anything that has grown within
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it as a private inheritance. The Activism is started and kept going on
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its course by the over-personal norms and values already referred to. It
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is the union of norm and will that constitutes the full action. Life's
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: greater meaning and value is, therefore, not a ready-made possession; it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is rather something already possessed, and a vision of something _more_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the distance to be possessed.[73] The presence of the Divine within
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the soul is not the same prior to the search and after the search. This
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is [p.212] one of the most distinctive features of Eucken's teaching,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and constitutes a necessary supplement to certain presentations of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Immanent Idealism prevalent in various forms to-day.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: When we pass to _Materialism_ in its various forms, we find Eucken
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conscious of its poverty and its caricature of life. It is caused by
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: excessive absorption in the sensuous object with all its manifold
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: relations. But it is possible to believe in all that it states; for it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: can never really say anything concerning the deeper meaning of spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life if for no other reason than that it cannot penetrate into life's
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deeper experiences. It is a stage in human thought which is passing
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: away. What will become of it after Professor Haeckel's passing is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: difficult to imagine. One thing at least is certain: as a complete
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: system of the universe or of life it is doomed.[74] A mechanical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: interpretation of the universe is legitimate: we may have to adopt more
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of such interpretations in the future. But there is no need for any
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: alarm from the sides of philosophy and religion. Their citadel is not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: built upon a _thing_, but upon a _thought_; and the gap between the two
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: increases in the degree in which our knowledge of Nature and Man
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: increases. Eucken has many great things to say on this subject in his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: larger works. Doubtless he would agree with some of the [p.213]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: advocates of _Naturalism_ in regard to the meaning of the physical
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: universe, but such agreement would not be an admission that _all_ had
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: been said that could be said concerning the need and the possibility of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a _Metaphysic of Life_.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The one word _More_ constitutes all the difference. This _More_, with
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eucken, is the beginning of a new order of existence and of value where
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the physical order ends. His work consists in interpreting this _More_,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and we have already seen whither the _More_ leads us: it leads us into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual norms and their values, and these in their turn led us into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Infinite Love in the Godhead. The failure to see the value of all this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is due to the inattention of the advocates of Naturalism in regard to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the non-sensuous structure of mind: the _Thing and its relations_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: monopolise them so completely that they are blind to every reality
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: non-sensuous in its nature, although they possess some amount of such
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality in their very knowledge and adoration of the _Thing_. Our
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: troubles will continue to accumulate, and the prospect of the future
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: will grow extremely dark, if the grip which physical things have on the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world to-day be not relaxed. The very physical powers which we have
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: helped to create, and which hitherto have proved of service to men, will
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: mean our destruction unless something of the _More_ which is beyond them
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be found as a possession and an activity within the governing centre of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life. This is Eucken's [p.214] plea over against the various forms of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the Naturalism and Materalism of our day. These are not enough for man.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: But man is so slow in recognising this fact. The appeal of Spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Idealism is considered to be something which is vague and useless. Our
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deepest reality and the source of all true energy have been robbed of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: their efficacy by our absorption in scraping together physical elements
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of chaff and dust. How often does Eucken show our dire poverty in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: midst of all this external plenty! The all-sufficiency of all forms of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Naturalism condemns itself through its failure to pass beyond itself.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Had there not been some who did pass beyond the _Thing and its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: relations_ the spiritual values of the race would have been annihilated.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: "As soon as we demand to pass beyond mere awareness to a genuine
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: knowledge, we discover our deplorable poverty, and must confess that
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: what is termed certain seems on clearer investigation to rest upon a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: totally insecure foundation."[75] "It is not natural science itself
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: which leads to naturalism, for, indeed, no natural science could arise
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: if reality exhausted itself in the measurements of naturalism; but it is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: rather the weakness of the conviction of the spiritual life; it is the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: failure of certitude in regard to the presence of a spiritual existence;
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it is the unclearness concerning the _inner_ conditions of all mental
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and spiritual activity which a shallow and popular philosophy [p.215]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: presents--it is all this which turns natural science into a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: materialistic naturalism."[76] The strength of materialistic _monism_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: does not lie in any proof of there being nothing but mechanism in this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: wide universe, but in its energetic propaganda against certain
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: traditional theological forms of ecclesiastical religion--forms which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: are rapidly being disowned by the leaders of religious thought. Even
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: monism concedes that "it is better being good than bad, better being
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: sane than mad." This concession, and the attempt to live according to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it, constitute a proof of the presence in some form of a non-sensuous
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality and value in the constructions of materialistic monism itself.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Hence, Eucken's conception of spiritual life cannot be got rid of after
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: all. It will remain so long as men live above the animal level and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: strive to ascend to something higher still.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: When the _neo-Kantian_ movement is examined, we find that its long and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: honourable history presents us with gains which cannot be measured. But
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: we have already noticed that in so far as this movement has specialised
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: within the domain of the connections of mind and body, and has attempted
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to reduce psychology to the limits of the relations between the two, it
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is largely outside the _inner_ meaning and value of the life of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consciousness. [p.216] Its work has proved useful in many important
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: respects. It has made man realise that the connection of body and mind
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is not so simple a matter as materialistic naturalism would lead us to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: suppose; and it has shown, on the whole, the impossibility of reducing
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: consciousness to mechanical elements. Even in the various forms of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: psycho-physical parallelism the factor of mind and meaning stands apart
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in its origin from the factors of bodily movement. But neo-Kantianism
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has developed on higher lines than those of physiological psychology. It
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has dealt with the presence of an inner world of thought--a world of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: values and judgments of values, of norms, imperatives, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: ideals--realities which are not presented in any scheme of natural
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: science. It is impossible to read such a great book as the late
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Professor Otto Liebmann's _Analysis der Wirklichkeit_[77] without
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: discovering this truth. In this great work, as well as in his _Gedanken
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: und Thatsachen_, Liebmann shows how man is more than a natural product.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.217] "Natural science," he tells us, "is a very useful, and, indeed,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: an indispensable handmaid to philosophy, but it is in no manner the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: first, the deepest, the most original basis of philosophy."[78]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Liebmann's successors, especially Windelband, Rickert, Muensterberg,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Adickes, and Vaihinger, work on similar lines. And there is a great deal
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in Eucken's teaching which tends in the same direction. But he goes a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: step further than all the neo-Kantians. We have already noticed how he
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: gives judgments of value and spiritual norms a _cosmic_ significance. He
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: finds that when these norms and values have awakened with great
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: clearness within man's spirit they inevitably lead to the conception of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the Godhead. And it is in this work that Eucken's Metaphysic of Life
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: becomes a _religious metaphysic_. As values and norms mean so much when
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: a reality is granted them by the truest of the neo-Kantians, they come
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to mean infinitely more when they are acknowledged as somehow
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: constituting the foundation and the acme of all existence. Eucken's main
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: desire is to establish such norms and values beyond the possibility of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: dispute and beyond the constant changes of Life-systems. They mean for
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: him what is present within their spiritual content as a realisation as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: well as the _More_ to which they still point. His teaching is not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: contradicted by anything in the neo-Kantian movement;[p.218] he accepts
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its transcendental reality and lifts it out of the realm of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individuality and of history into a cosmic realm. After having followed
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the implications of the neo-Kantian movement so far, he feels compelled
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to take the next step. For unless that next step is taken, some of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deepest potencies of human nature fail to come to flower and fruit. When
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the step is taken, they do blossom and bear fruit. Is not this a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: sufficient justification for taking the "next step"? It is; for man
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: cannot allow any potency of his being to remain dormant without
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: suffering a loss; and on this highest level of all the loss must be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: incalculable. "Thou hast created us for Thyself, and our heart will
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: never find its rest until it rests on Thee." That confession of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Augustine is Eucken's confession also; and it is the implication which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: such a confession contains that constitutes the significance of his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: message to the world. He is in the line not only of the philosophers but
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the prophets and the mystics. The ladder of knowledge reaches, like
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Jacob's ladder, up to heaven itself--to that pure atmosphere where
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: knowledge, merged in a deeper reality, becomes something so different
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: from what it was before. An eternal blessedness has now become the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possession of man.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eucken has a great deal to say regarding the _Historical_ Life-systems
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the present day. [p.219] He is aware that the neglect by German
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: thinkers of the fundamental importance of Hegel's teaching on this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: question has meant a heavy loss. That loss is already perceived, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Hegel's value in the realm of the Philosophy of History is being
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: rediscovered. Men are more and more feeling the necessity of conceding a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: validity and objectivity to the concepts of History. The work of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: late Professor Dilthey[79] in this respect is of great importance, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: has strong affinities with Eucken's teaching on the same subject. But
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Dilthey's objectivity and validity stopped short of religion in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: sense in which religion is presented by Eucken. Dilthey gave the norms
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of History a transcendental objectivity and considered them sufficient
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: for man. But Eucken, as already stated, while granting all this and even
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: insisting upon it, finds that the norms of History do not include the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: whole that human nature needs. The "next step" has to be taken whereby a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: reality is revealed beyond the confines of the best collective
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: experiences of the human race. Once more, we are landed in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conception of the Godhead. The step became inevitable, because the best
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.220] historical concepts, in their totality, pointed to something
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: still beyond themselves.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: During the past few years Eucken has devoted much attention to the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Life-system presented in _Pragmatism_. He is alive to the value of much
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of the work of the late Professor William James and of Dr F.C.S.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Schiller. He feels that Absolute Idealism is too abstract and too remote
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: from life to move the human will. It is too much like placing a man
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: before a mountain, and asking him to remove it. The very magnitude of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the object weakens instead of strengthening the will. Pragmatism has the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: merit of insisting that the task be done piecemeal, so that man may not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: lose heart at the very outset. And some kind of goal is present in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Pragmatism. But Eucken's main objection to Pragmatism is that, however
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: adequate it may be at the beginning of the enterprise, it will tend, as
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: time passes, to turn man in the direction of the line of least
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: resistance, and so be degraded to the level of the ordinary life and its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: petty demands.[80] His Activism is entirely different from James's
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Pragmatism. James depended too much upon the "span of the moment" and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: its immediate experience. There is in this "span" often no cosmic
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: conviction present in consciousness to proclaim that the action is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.221] "worth while" at all costs. While constantly demanding the need
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of effort in order to experience the deeper potencies of spiritual life,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Eucken insists that such effort can enter into a current only in so far
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: as norms and values are clearly perceived as the meaning and goal of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: spiritual life. A _universal_ of meaning and value must be perceived,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: however imperfectly it may be, before the individual can call his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deepest nature into activity. And what is such a _universal_ but
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something beyond the flow of the moment and beyond the realm of ordinary
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: daily life? Such a _universal_, too, must have an existence of its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: own--an existence and a value which are beyond the opinions of any
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: individual or of any group of individuals, even if such a group were to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: include the whole human race. It is clear, then, why Eucken parts
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: company with Pragmatism.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: If, finally, we view his attitude towards the _Religious_ Life-systems
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of our generation, we find words of warning and of encouragement. His
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: whole work culminates in religion. But he teaches us that we have to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: learn from the sides of knowledge already presented in this chapter. And
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: it may be said that the Christian Church (or any other Church) has yet
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to learn this lesson. It still seeks to find its revelation in what
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: _was_, and in modes which come constantly into direct conflict with the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: results of the various Life-systems already referred to. It wants the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fruits of religion without tilling [p.222] the ground and nurturing its
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: plants. Its insistence on placing the basis of religion in myth and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: miracle dooms it to a greater disaster in the future than even in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: past. Eucken sees no hope for a "revival" of religion in the soul until
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: an inverted order of conceiving reality takes place. The religious
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: synthesis from the intellectual side is to be obtained by passing
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: through the grades of reality explicit in the various Life-systems, and
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: by abstaining from the imposition of barriers which forbid anyone
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: roaming and "ruminating" within these. If one condition is obeyed, this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: is the most fruitful way to construct a new religious metaphysic which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: will supplant traditional theology. That condition is that the various
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Life-systems form a kind of scale which extends from Matter up to the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Godhead. The new religious metaphysic will then mean a real philosophy
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of values.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Does this constitute an impossible task for the Christian Church? It
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: will remain impossible so long as we look upon the essence of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Christianity as something which descends upon us apart from the exertion
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of our own spiritual potencies. It is a consolation to know that the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: highest reality may be experienced without having to undergo a training
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in the methods and implications of science, history, or metaphysics. But
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the experience here cannot possibly mean so much as the experience which
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: passes through and beyond the implications of knowledge to the [p.223]
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Divine. Such an experience as the latter must be richer in content. And
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: even apart from this, it produces something of value on the intellectual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: side--something which grants religion a security in the eyes of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: world. When the Church tends in this direction, its faith will come into
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: comradeship with the various branches of human knowledge as these reveal
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: themselves on level above level. Christianity has nothing to fear, but
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: everything to gain, from the development of all the branches of human
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: knowledge. Its source being Spiritual and Eternal, why should opposition
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: be presented to any development of the lower realities in science,

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: It will probably prove helpful at the conclusion to indicate the main
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: contents of Eucken's greatest works in order that the reader who turns
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: to them for the first time may be able somewhat to find his bearings.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The whole of Eucken's works turn around the conception of the _spiritual
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life_. This fact must be constantly borne in mind. The term has been
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: repeated so often in all the previous chapters that the reader may be
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: oppositions of the ages to religion are brought on the stage, and are
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: made to reveal their best and their worst. He shows how every system of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: thought, devoid of the experience and activity of the deepest soul,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: fails to engender religion. He shows over against all this the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: intellectual warrant for religion, and passes from this to the personal
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: search by the soul for what is warranted by the intellect and by the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: deepest needs of one's own being. This has been the meaning of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: religions of the world, and this meaning finds its culmination in
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Christianity.

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: Eucken is at present engaged upon the [p.242] completion of a work of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: great importance dealing with _The Theory of Knowledge_. His system has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: been stated to be in need of this important corner-stone, and he has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: hastened to meet the demand. The book will deal with the "grounds" of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the life of the spirit in an even more fundamental manner than any of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: his books. A preparatory work, small in bulk--_Erkennen und Leben_--has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: just appeared in German, and will be issued in English in the spring of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: In _Erkennen und Leben_ Eucken shows the need of clearness in regard to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the concept of the spiritual life. This work is an introduction to his
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: forthcoming work--_The Theory of Knowledge_. He shows that the Problem
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of Knowledge can only be answered through a further clarification of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Problem of Life. It is, therefore, necessary to show what such a Life is
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and how it may be lived, and, finally, how it makes Knowledge possible.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: This is the only way by which the final convictions of Life are able to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: possess greater depth and duration.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Knowledge is possible only in so far as man participates in a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: self-subsistent life. Without such a self-subsistent life many
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: intellectual achievements are possible, but they do not deserve the name
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: of Knowledge.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Such a self-subsistent life must be operative in the foundation of our
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: nature, but it must constantly receive its material from the most
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [p.243] important meanings and values of the world. The self-subsistent
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: life dare not feed on the mere analysis of consciousness or on the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: material which it already possesses.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: History shows how a self-subsistent life is not created through the mere
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: succession of events, but is always found as a life which is superior to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: the perpetual changes of Time. Consequently, every real Knowledge has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: something _sub specie aeternitatis_ as its essence, and this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: differentiates it from all mere relativism.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The movement of History culminates alternately in _Concentration_ on the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: one hand, and in _Expansion_ on the other: _Positive_ and _Critical_
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: epochs alternate. Both aspects are necessary for the growth of life.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: In modern times the growth of the Expansion-side of life has destroyed
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: in a large measure the equilibrium of life; and the task to-day is to
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: construct a new Concentration-side.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Such a new Concentration is possible: the experience of History
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: testifies to its presence in several epochs; and there is a deep longing
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: for it in many quarters to-day.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: In order to attain to such a Concentration the "dead-level" life of the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: present must be overcome, and a turn must take place towards a new
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Metaphysic of Life.
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Such is the problem to-day, and no complete answer is to be found in the
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: past systems of Metaphysics. "The possibilities of Life and [p.244] of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: Knowledge are in no way exhausted, but it is only through our own
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: courage and actions that the possibilities can become actualities"
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: (_Erkennen und Leben_, p. 161).
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: The various systems of Thought need a synthesis which will include them
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: all. It is difficult to-day to obtain a theory of life which does not
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: leave out of account some essential elements. Is there a possibility of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: discovering such a synthesis? I believe that Eucken's works answer this
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: question. But we wait eagerly for the appearance of his greatest work,
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: and I think that, when it appears, he will more than ever deserve
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: [86] Eucken follows Kant in the fact that after the union of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: subject and object has taken place a _new kind of objectivity_ has
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: to be taken into account. This result has to be admitted before
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: knowledge becomes possible at all. Eucken has not dealt in a
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: thorough manner with this problem, although several hints are given
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: concerning the importance of this transcendental aspect in Kant's
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: philosophy. The implications of such a _new_ kind of objectivity
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy
author: Jones, W. Tudor (William Tudor)

text: avoid the danger of subjectivism, on the one hand, and of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: empiricism on the other hand. Eucken's forthcoming _Theory of
title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

title: An Interpretation of Rudolf Eucken's Philosophy

text: Leben_ certain aspects of the problem are touched.
